It is quite clear that we have a vast number of people in Australia who are interested in taking a stake in some of the great Australian companies. So we have to ask ourselves why it is that anyone would be opposed to privatisation. I heard Senator Ellison give Mr Stephen Smith a bit of a pat on the back for his positive approach. But Mr Smith has a very serious problem in this whole policy area because he knows, as well as we do, that we are on the right track. If he had his own way he would be arguing it as loudly as he could. He wanted to do that when he worked for Mr Keating and he wants to do it now. But of course he has to pay lip-service to the unions which insist that you do not go down this path while in opposition. What he had to say in a press conference the other day—apart from trotting out that usual dishonesty about this all being linked to quality of service, when we know that Telstra has had problems with quality of service for the last decade—was this:
Well, we've consistently said we regard Telstra as an important part of our national infrastructure and on that basis we wouldn't privatise it.
That did not stop them with the airports and the airlines. He went on to say:
Before you would contemplate a privatisation of Telstra you might want to ensure that we had a fully competitive telecommunications market.

In other words, it is optional: you might want to. Clearly, they do not have any opposition in principle: it is simply premature. So if Labor get into government, hey presto, they decide there is sufficient competition in the telecommunications arena and they suddenly get themselves a full privatisation with all that flows from it. It is rank hypocrisy, it is clearly against the national interest, it is utterly opportunistic, and it ignores the wishes of all of those Australians who not only want to have a stake in Telstra but also want to ensure that they get the right capital gains tax regime. I hope Mr Smith will at least compensate for his opportunism on that front by urging his party to support the capital gains tax proposal. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Alston representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. I refer to the statement today made by the minister for education concerning the $259 million over three years application of public moneys to bribe workers in universities into signing workplace agreements. I quote the reference to the `meeting of the government policy objectives' as was outlined in what is now quite clearly the disgraced cabinet submission. How does this policy differ from the $25 million which was indicated in the previous cabinet submission? Does the minister approve of the policy, or does he view this as an act of coercion? In light of the Prime Minister's repudiation of Dr Kemp and his draconian policies last week, and of course in question time again today, will the Howard government repudiate Dr Kemp's proposal to coerce academic staff by using taxpayers' money?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Here we go again! The good old class warfare is alive and well. They kept him quiet during the Victorian state election, but I suppose they cannot keep him out of the game indefinitely if they have him up here in Canberra for six years at a time. Senator Carr could not help himself; that is his problem. He purported to quote from a cabinet submission. He could not help himself because he asked whether I agree that Dr Kemp was arguing for $259 million over three years to bribe workers in universities. I have not looked closely at it, but I would be very surprised if any such term was used in the cabinet submission. All it does, of course, is suggest that what Senator Carr is about is upping the rhetoric; in other words, trying to ensure that those who have put him here in the first place get their money's worth by arguing about draconian changes and coercion.

question.para: The reality is, if you make proposals that are designed to bring about sensible change as far as Senator Carr is concerned, if you try to do it by money rather than, as Labor would do, by trying to change the law and impose whatever ideological view of the world they might have at that particular time, if you actually try to accompany it with measures that are designed to bring about change and, at the same time, transfer money, then that, of course, is coercion if you do not like it. If you do like it, you think it is a very sensible incentive structure; if you do not, it is a bribe. All I can say is: go away, get your rhetoric right and go back to policy formulation stages. Get a bit of advice from anyone on your side who might be interested in policy and you will see that we do have a commit ment to the university sector and we do want to improve education in Australia.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, has the legal advice flagged in paragraph 22 of Dr Kemp's higher education cabinet submission provided to the government been on `minimising the risk of legal challenge to Dr Kemp's reforms'? Who is providing that legal advice and will that advice be made public?

question.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are senators further down the chamber shouting across the chamber and your behaviour is disorderly.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —There it is: game, set and match! Senator Carr did not in any shape or form attempt to justify the use of the words `bribery and coercion'. He simply moves on to some utterly unrelated question about legal advice. If he is serious about coercion and bribery, perhaps he might like to explain to us why the Premier of New South Wales is supporting the press ganging of workers and compulsory backdoor membership requiring people to pay a percentage of their union's annual dues, irrespective of whether they are union members, bringing about a windfall to the New South Wales unions of some $231 million—no doubt very helpful for the ALP's campaign war chest. Why should they be regarded as volunteers? They have obviously been forced to do something they do not want to do, that is, they do not want to join a union. If you want to have a debate about bribery and coercion, let us start there.

question.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The behaviour on my left is unacceptable.

—My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Why does the Australian government, in acting in accordance with international law, recognise the right of the East Timorese people to the right of self-determination, yet in the case of Australia's indigenous peoples denies them this fundamental right, substitut ing it with a nebulous concept unheard of and unrecognised in international law, namely, self-empowerment? Will not this inconsistency inevitably open Australia to charges of gross hypocrisy and double standards, especially from the nations in the Asia-Pacific region which are monitoring very carefully our actions following Australia's support for the right of the East Timorese to self-determination?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ridgeway for the question. The term `self-determination' means different things to different people. There is no fixed definition. I hear the laughter from the other side. It is just evidence of their absolute ignorance on this particular matter. The term `self-determination' appears in many publications but there is no fixed meaning. To some people it may mean separate nations within a nation, and many speak of it in that way. The terms `self-empowerment' and `self-management' are considered by some to be more a recognition of an internal structure that exists in this country as applied to the indigenous people of this country. The government certainly supports the principle of indigenous people exercising varying degrees of control over aspects of their affairs. You would recall that I gave an instruction to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to look at structures for self-management within the Torres Strait Islands. They came up with a recommendation which is being discussed by the Torres Strait Islanders.

answer.para: What that meant in that context was that they should have greater control over the administrative structures within the Torres Strait Islands, not that they should separate themselves off as a separate nation. Yet to some people there, that is what it means. In the international context, this matter was raised before the United Nations working group on the draft declaration in December last year and many delegations expressed concerns about the ill-defined nature of self-determination. Australia's position was explicitly supported by the United States of America and the United Kingdom.

In reply to Senator Ridgeway's question, I do not see a disparity in that between a popularly elected people having a vote—over 90 per cent—seeking in that context self-determination and control of their own separate part of the country, as opposed to, in our context, trying to draw an analogy between the indigenous people of this country within part of the Australian nation as a whole. I do not believe that analogy is valid, so I reject the implication in that question.
We have progressed along the line since coming to government. We have done a lot more than the Labor Party in this regard.

talk.start.para: —Absolute rubbish!

—Senator Bolkus was not present two weeks ago when Gatjil Djerkurra, the Chairman of ATSIC, and I jointly released a paper on regionalisation, so that in those parts of the country where there are major numbers of indigenous people they can take control of their own destiny in relation to the administrative structures. That green paper is available.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Those opposite who are trying to interrupt should go and read that paper so they will get a bit more knowledge in this regard and understand the direction the indigenous people of this country wish to pursue. I would advise them to get hold of that. I will be happy to send a copy to Senator Bolkus if he so desires, but I doubt if he would be bothered reading it because he has shown no interest in these matters at all.

answer.para: But we are progressing along these lines to give people the opportunity to control matters within their own regions. It also brings up the problem, which is being discussed, of the introduction of control of legal matters, particularly within Arnhem Land. The people there believe that they should have the right—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Can he officially confirm that the position that is being put is the one that is being put by the Australian government and advocated at a meeting of the working group of the United Nations Human Rights Commission concerning the Draft Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples? Hasn't this also been confirmed in a publication from the minister's office rebutting myths about Australia's indigenous human rights? Won't this put at risk the whole question of `reconciliation'?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Ridgeway for the supplementary question. No, I do not believe that it will put at risk the question of reconciliation. Reconciliation is something that has to be determined by each and every one of us within Australia. I do not believe that any actions of the United Nations in this regard will cause great dissent within this country. It is up to each and every one of us, every individual in this country—every Australian has an obligation—to pursue reconciliation. Any discussion of this at the working group of indigenous peoples within the United Nations will have an influence, obviously. I understand that group is meeting at the moment in the United Nations. But reconciliation within Australia is of far more fundamental importance to each of us within this country as Australian citizens, both indigenous and non-indigenous. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications. How does the government justify its decision to support Telstra's decision to increase the fees for its 12 non-executive directors by a massive 53 per cent, to $1.15 million, when Telstra's main competitor, Optus, only pay their seven non-executive directors $166,000 in total? Why is a Telstra non-executive director worth over $90,000, while his or her counterpart in Optus is worth only $24,000?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The judgment about what they are worth in the private sector is generally a matter largely for the directors themselves, usually taken on advice from the remuneration committee, which in most listed companies would operate at arm's length. There is a huge difference in terms of the size of Telstra and Optus. Optus is a minnow compared to Telstra. What is significant about Telstra is that it has generally underpaid its directors by reference to market levels. In other words, there is no shortage of reviews which demonstrate what the going rate is in the marketplace.
—Do they apply to everyone in Telstra, do they?
—Order! Senator Carr, you are out of order. There is an appropriate time to debate this matter. That is at the end of question time, not during the time of answering.

—I know Senator Carr would like to see a Labor government using the power of direction to decide what every single employee amongst those 55,000 ought to receive, but that is not the way the system operates. The directors are perfectly entitled to take the view that by reference to market standards their levels have been below the going rate. When you are talking about the largest company in Australia you expect it to pay world's best rates if it is to attract top quality people. I hope none of you objected to Mr Blount being brought in from the United States. Mr Blount would come from a culture where—
—You appointed them. You appointed them out of political favouritism.

—Order! Senator Schacht, you have been interjecting in just about every answer during question time today. I point out to you what the standing orders say about interrupting other speakers and the consequences.

—I am simply making the point that if you want to attract world class people to run the company, and we did have Mr Blount running the company for more than five years, Mr Blount was perfectly entitled to point to the fact that his counterparts in telcos in other countries would have been earning a great deal more than he was. If that is the going rate, then I do not have any problem with it. What I seriously object to, however, is situations where CEOs take very significant increases in their own levels of remuneration, despite the fact that the company is not performing very well. I think that is out of kilter. I think it is a responsi bility the directors have to ensure that the company has the capacity to afford to pay those rates. Beyond that it is a matter of judgment.

answer.para: If Optus chooses to underpay its directors—and I do not know whether it is; by market standards it sounds as though it might be—and if Telstra chooses only to go close to the market level but certainly not well beyond it, then I would have thought that is the way the system ought to be operating. I do not begrudge those directors the entitlement to receive something that is commensurate with the level of responsibility which they accept. We all want them to take very big decisions on a regular basis—decisions that affect every Australian—and we want to have the best possible people there, and they are entitled to receive market remuneration.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. My question to the minister went to the government's decision to justify the decision of the board of management of Telstra. How does the minister justify to ordinary Australians on average incomes a 53 per cent increase in fees to directors of Telstra at a time when the organisation is under increasing criticism for failing to deliver on basic services to its customers?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —As I have said many times, the complaints about quality of service go back a decade, and that is one of the responsibilities which I think the directors in general, and Dr Switkowski in particular, take very seriously. To say that directors' remuneration has gone up by 53 per cent is irrelevant unless you go back and look at the base point. I think you will find that they have not had an increase for quite some years, and if you then look at the absolute level of remuneration I think you will find it is very much in line with the going rate. Those two factors do not suggest to me that they are being overpaid. I do not think we need to justify that to the Australian public any more than we need to justify allowing the private sector to make its own arrangements. As far as we are concerned, I think the extent of our responsibility was in endorsing an overall increase in the allocation. It is then a matter for the directors themselves to strike the balance within that limit. That is the way the system has worked, and I think it works pretty well.

—My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. I have only just been able to hand him a copy of a report from the consultants DuPont and Bergin to Pangea. That report targets South Australia for a nuclear waste dump measuring 14 square kilometres and up to five kilometres deep, sited 300 to 1,000 kilometres from, presumably, Whyalla or Port Augusta. I ask the minister: will he let the Blair government, as a 70 per cent shareholder through British Nuclear Fuels Ltd in Pangea, know that it is time for them to rack off and not to see Australia as a repository for their waste? Secondly, I ask the minister: will he support legislation—or indeed initiate legislation if he finds the legislation I bring in unacceptable—for a national assurance that Australia cannot in the future be used as a nuclear waste dump? (Time expired)

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —The Blair government is indeed a Labour government, but I do not think it would be appropriate or diplomatic of me to tell it to rack off. I have written to Pangea, as Senator Brown knows, and made it abundantly clear to them that the government totally opposes—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are far too many senators interjecting.

—I have stated in this place repeatedly and publicly, and I have written to Pangea themselves restating this, the government's very firm opposition to the Pangea proposal to establish in Australia a repository for international radioactive waste materials. That is the clear policy of this government. There is no prospect of that changing. I confess and admit that Pangea is a most persistent applicant.

answer.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are too many senators engaged in conversation across the chamber and amongst themselves. It is hard to hear.

—Pangea did make it clear from the outset a long time ago that Western Australia and South Australia were the two states that suited their proposal, but both the governments in those two states have made it clear that they are totally opposed to it and would not issue any of the relevant permits or licences needed for such a proposal to advance. Radioactive substances are a prohibited import under the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations. We believe that the regulatory regime is sufficient to ensure that our policy will be adhered to. I know that is the Labor Party's policy as well. It seems to me that there is absolutely no prospect under any government in Australia for the Pangea proposal to proceed.

answer.para: It is true that there is a discretion for the Minister for Health and Aged Care under the customs regulations to give written approval for the importation of radioactive substances but, as the former Labor government discovered when it sought to perhaps change that, that is an essential part of our managing responsibly our own radioactive wastes. We have sent and will be sending the spent fuel rods from Lucas Heights overseas for processing, and then we will bring back—as we should as the responsible source of the waste—the radioactive waste from those fuel rods. It is necessary under the customs regulations for the minister for health, as the minister responsible for ARPANSA, to issue a specific permit to enable that radioactive waste to be returned to Australia so that we can responsibly look after our own waste. That is our policy: that every country involved in the nuclear fuel cycle should make its own arrangements for looking after its own waste. We are not going to look after anybody else's waste, but we will responsibly look after our own.

talk.start.para: —I thank the minister for that reassurance. Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the fact that 93 per cent of South Australians, according to a recent poll, oppose even low level nuclear waste being reposited in South Australia, let alone high level and intensely radioactive material, including plutonium, which Pangea proposes to—
—Where would you want to send it—Tasmania?

—They will try Tasmania next. They are going to obviously go right around the lot. In view of that fact, will the minister look again at legislation analogous to that in Western Australia, which I am sure would get multipartisan support here, to give the South Australian people a reassurance that there is no loophole through which Pangea can keep its hopes alive?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —I think I have given all the assurances that I can possibly give. There is no loophole. The Pangea proposal will go nowhere. I do not know about the poll you mentioned, but of course radioactive waste repositories are not popular. Nevertheless, we are committed to establishing a low level waste repository in South Australia. As I understand it, the federal opposition understands that and accepts that reality. We will proceed with that. We are going through all the relevant procedures to do that properly and sensibly, but it will be for our own radioactive waste and not for anybody else's.

—My question is to Senator Newman, as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Does the minister agree that, if you apply a real interest rate to a loan, then the longer you take to pay it off the more interest you will pay? Doesn't this mean that, under the Howard government's newly revealed approach to higher education, a woman's decision to take time off to start a family will cost her thousands of dollars extra compared to her male colleagues? Won't her debt be growing while she is on maternity leave, with the interest being capitalised and massively increasing the debt potentially to well over $100,000?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —It is interesting that Senator Crowley has taken this long to realise that interest rates actually cost people money. It is a pity she did not think about that when Labor had interest rates right up at 17 or more per cent. I would also point out that the Prime Minister has made it very clear that the interest rates that she was talking about are not going to be applied at all to students.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Did the minister raise this detrimental impact on women when the loan at real interest rates proposal was considered by cabinet—back in June this year and again this morning—or did she meekly let this outrageous policy continue to be developed by Dr Kemp as her Prime Minister did and does?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Of course, when Senator Crowley was a minister, she was not a member of cabinet, but if she had been she would have realised that you do not discuss what happens in cabinet in the Senate.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. Will the minister inform the Senate how the initial sale of Telstra has helped community groups across Australia in their efforts to protect our natural environment? What further benefits will flow to these groups from the sale of Telstra 2?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable senator for that important question. It is true that the first sale of Telstra delivered major benefits to the Australian economy by allowing the government to pay back some of Labor's debt. The Senate will recall, of course, that when the Howard government came to government the Commonwealth debt was some $96 billion; that was in the year 1995-96. It has now declined by $24 billion, and this has been as a result of sensible economic management: getting the deficit—$10 billion—reversed to a surplus and repaying debt from the sale of some assets. Of course, Labor, when it sold capital assets, used the funds against recurrent expenditure, and nothing was left afterwards.

answer.para: So, yes, it has helped the economy and that is very important. But the sale of Telstra 1 also delivered a significant bonus to our environment. The first Telstra sale allowed this government to invest $1.25 billion in the Natural Heritage Trust—the largest environmental action plan ever undertaken by an Australian government. Of course, the Natural Heritage Trust was a commitment made by the coalition during the 1996 election campaign and, unlike under the Labor Party, it has been delivered in full. Madam President, you might remember that during that election campaign the then Labor environment minister said about the coalition's NHT promise:
It's now clear to anyone with the most rudimentary understanding of Australian politics that the Trust Fund will never see the light of day.

That, of course, was Senator Faulkner, the then Labor environment minister. He got it wrong, not as embarrassing, of course, as the time he smeared the Baillieu family by claiming that dead members of that family were benefiting from a grant to the Trust—he has not yet apologised, I might say—but wrong all the same. Through the Natural Heritage Trust, the Howard government is backing the efforts of community groups across Australia. The community identifies their local environmental problems, they work out a local solution and they become part of that solution by providing the on-ground work force. The Natural Heritage Trust then provides them with the financial support they need to implement their plan.

So, far from Senator Faulkner's claims that the trust was a cruel and deliberate hoax, the trust has in fact already delivered more than $700 million for environmental and sustainable agricultural projects. The government recently has announced a further $185 million to fund more than 2,600 projects in this financial year—$48 million in New South Wales, $38 million in Victoria, almost $30 million in Queensland, $29 million in Western Australia, $24 million in South Australia, $14 million in Tasmania, just under a million in the ACT, and an announcement is still to come in the Northern Territory. The Telstra 2 sale will help us build upon these environmental efforts because the second Telstra sale will deliver an additional $250 million to the Natural Heritage Trust. Of course, the sale will also deliver other benefits, particularly for rural and regional Australia, including $70 million for a network of rural transaction centres, an expansion of the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund and funds for increased access to the Internet. None of these would have been possible under a Labor government. Under this government more money is being invested than ever before in the greatest capital asset of all, our natural capital. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Newman, in her capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Is the minister aware that the Defence Force child-care centre in Perth, the Sunny Child Care Centre, which serves the families of the personnel of the SAS barracks at Swanbourne, is having its child-care places cut, from 47 to 28 from January next year, as part of a privatisation program? Isn't it the case that the centre serves the families of Swanbourne barracks personnel serving with the multinational forces in East Timor? Why was the number of places reduced and can the minister guarantee that defence families will not lose access to child-care services as a result of these measures?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I am not a Western Australian senator, but I visited the child-care centre at Swanbourne a number of years ago. I have no idea why there is any cut, if there is any, and I suggest to you that it may be a matter for the local authorities. It could be local government or the Army. I have not heard any information that Defence or my department are involved in that. I will get information for you, Senator.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the minister seeking some information, and I assure her that my information is accurate. Wasn't the original justification for Defence Force child care to ensure that Defence Force families, in times of emergency when service personnel may be overseas on active duty, had access to respite care and additional services because of the stress placed on families? My concern and the concern of the residents is that that not be reduced. I would like to know what measures have been put in place to ensure that those families continue to get the same access and the same service that they have had in recent years when the government has cut the places that are available at these centres.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I have already made it clear that I do not know who made the cuts in places. I agree that respite assistance for people whose extended family is on the other side of the continent is important, but I also remind the Senate that it was a very slow Labor government that came to support child care in defence establishments. As the shadow minister for defence science and personnel, I spent a very long time trying to sensitise the previous government to the needs of defence families. I will certainly get you an answer, and I support the general principle that you are talking about, but as to why there are any changes in the places, I do not know.
—Because you are privatising it!
—Oh, come away! We're not privatising it.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is the minister aware that the government's ongoing refusal to decide on citizenship for East Timorese asylum seekers who arrived after 1992 means that they cannot attend university or TAFE colleges unless they pay thousands of dollars in overseas student fees? Is the minister also aware that the children of East Timorese asylum seekers have been denied access to public education for three to six months until their visitors' visas expire? Is the minister aware that the Catholic schools are taking in many Timorese students free of charge? Minister, given the importance of education to the rebuilding of East Timor, why is Australia not making a concerted effort to give Timorese in Australia the best possible access to our schools and universities?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —The East Timor situation is a very serious one indeed, and particularly in relation to those East Timorese who are in Australia. I am not aware of the matters that Senator Allison raises, but I will certainly look into them and take them on notice.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister to consider the pain and trauma that is experienced by East Timorese coming to Australia and to acknowledge that denying them a public education is exacerbating that pain and trauma. Isn't it the case that the federal government has no coherent policy on education for the children of asylum seekers in detention in Australia?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Special Minister of State

talk.start.para: —I am not the minister for education, so I do not have that detail to hand. I will certainly take it on notice. What we have done in relation to East Timorese asylum seekers is on the record. Minister Ruddock mentioned this just the other day. I will look into these matters and get back to Senator Allison.

—My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. My question concerns funding to child-care centres in the electorate of Bass, which is centred on Launceston, the minister's home town and the site of her electorate office. Can the minister confirm that, according to data from her own department, child-care assistance and capital grants funding to the eight community child-care centres in Bass has fallen from $1,547,891 in 1995-96 to an estimated $887,694 in 1998-99? This is a drop of $660,197, or 43 per cent. Can the minister give any credible explanation for this 43 per cent drop in community child-care funding in her home town of Launceston? Or will she simply find someone to blame in the department for releasing this figure?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —First of all I make it absolutely crystal clear there have been no funding cuts in child care in 1998-99 in Tasmania—none! As far as the detail of Bass is concerned, Senator Denman may be relying on a survey conducted by the member for Bass rather than that of an independent organisation. Senator Denman shakes her head; she may not be relying on that. If that is the case, it may be that she is not aware that many workers who use child care in Tasmania generally have casual or contract work. They use care only when they are working, and this can be very variable, especially in a depressed economy—despite the fact that Tasmania now has the `benefit' of a majority Labor government. It seems to have been pretty complacent about encouraging investment. We are still waiting for the sorts of projects that will provide employment to people in Bass.

answer.para: I would also point out the flexible working arrangements, which are now very much more helpful to parents who have responsibilities for children, which provide families with more options for managing their work and their child-care responsibilities. The vast majority of Tasmanian families use formal child care on a part-time basis—an average of around 17 hours paid per week. Since we came into government, people have not been paid for child care that was not provided to them, which was the case under Labor—you could have child care paid for more than 50 hours a week and not be receiving that child care which the taxpayer was funding. If there have been changes in the level of funding, Senator, I suggest you look at some of those reasons for why that might be. I would also suggest that you look at the fact that in the recent year or so, Tasmania is down about 2,000 children in the child-care age group, partly because of the lack of live births in Tasmania and partly as families are moving out of the state because of lack of work. All these things put together make a difference in how much money comes into any one electorate.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. That data did come from the department, Minister. Does the minister recall claiming in a radio talkback session on this issue on 5 October that Tasmania's child-care problems were due to the state having a `Rolls-Royce' model of child care in that the staff-child ratio for babies—that is, babies from zero to two years of age—was one in three? In fact, Tasmania has not had this ratio for two years and was forced to increase the ratio to the more common one in five in 1997, following the aboli tion of the operational subsidy to community based child care. Does the minister still believe that Tasmania has a Rolls-Royce model of child care?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The information about the ratio for people caring for babies came to me from two sources: firstly, my department and, secondly, from child-care proprietors or managers in Tasmania. You may not like the description, Senator, but it does highlight the fact that state governments determine the ratio of staff to children. The federal government does not determine fees, nor does it determine the ratio of staff to children in child-care centres by age. Therefore, if Tasmania is very out of kilter with other states, as it also is in aged care—where our costs for nursing and the occupational health and safety claims are much greater than in many other states—then our organisations carry a heavy overhead burden which has to be looked at in determining whether families can afford child care. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Regional Services, Territories and Local Government. Given the float of shares for ownership of a further 16 per cent of Telstra by the Australian public, would the minister please inform the Senate how the proceeds will be used to enhance regional Australia's infrastructure? How will this benefit the lives of regional Australians?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —Senator Brownhill will be interested to know that the government is investing the money from the sale of Telstra in infrastructure, much of it in rural and regional Australia. That is so unlike the previous government, the Labor government. When they sold everything that moved—the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas—they simply invested the capital proceeds in day-to-day living expenses, the recurrent expenses of government. So, Senator Brownhill, unlike the Labor Party, we will be putting it into infrastructure. We are not just flogging Telstra to a single company, as you might recall the former Labor leader wanted to do—you will remember Mr Keating wanted to sell Telstra in one lump sum to BHP—we are selling it to the ordinary mums and dads of Australia, but the money they pay for those shares will go into a lot of infrastructure projects.

answer.para: Senator Hill mentioned the great investment we are making in our natural heritage. In addition to that, we will be putting some $45 million into a project called Local Government Online to build up the telecommunications infrastructure for local government to allow them to keep up with the new millennium. In addition, we will be putting in $120 million to establish a television fund to expand SBS TV and to fix transmission black spots in parts of rural and regional Australia. I know Senator Brownhill will be very interested in that. We will be giving up to $150 million for untimed local call access to some 37,000 families and households located in the old pastoral zones, the outer extended zones, of remote Australia to enable them to call in at local call costs. We will also be spending some $70 million on rural transaction centres—that is, our program of putting banking facilities, transaction facilities, back into the small country towns, which the banks left during the term of Labor's government. Those transaction centres will re-establish in those smaller country towns real infrastructure, real transaction centres and real communications areas.

We will also be putting $36 million into a program called Points of Presence in regional Australia. That means that all Australians, no matter where they live, will be able to access the Internet at the cost of a local call. Again, I know that Senator Brownhill has made a lot of submissions on that. As well, we are putting in $20 million to expand regional telecommunications in remote and isolated island communities, particularly on Cocos (Keeling) and Christmas islands, Norfolk Island and even down in Antarctica. The money we get from the sale of Telstra will be put back into that telecommunications infrastructure.

So it is a great initiative. I just wish the Labor Party would not be so negative. They opposed the sale of Telstra; they opposed the sale of a further 16 per cent of Telstra. They do not want any of these infrastructure reinvestments. As Cheryl Kernot said, of course, if Labor were in government she would be worried about them selling it. I would be worried, too, not about the fact that they were going to sell it but that if they sold it, they would just put the money back into recurrent expenditure. They would not put it into the infrastructure that is so desperately needed. I do ask the Labor Party to think about that. I know that presenting policies might involve a policy reversal for many in the ALP, but I do urge it upon them.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I have some additional information for Senator Allison, which was requested on 14 October. I wish to table it.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Senator Newman has tabled that material and she is entitled, of course, without the leave of the Senate to do so. Can I suggest, Madam President, given this is extra information in response to a question—and I am not directing this specifically at Senator Newman; I notice this is a trend that has developed over recent sitting weeks and months—I really do think that the appropriate course of action for an answer providing further information to a question that has been taken on notice by a minister is that that particular answer should be incorporated in the Hansard record. It is an important part of the record and is directly in response to a question without notice that has been asked in this place.

interjection.para: I do not specifically address the concerns about what Senator Newman has done on this occasion, but it is a pattern that is developing that is outside the spirit of the way this place has worked previously. I think more details of an answer to a question without notice that has been taken on notice by a minister should be incorporated in Hansard for the benefit of all senators—and, frankly, for the public record. It is very difficult to access this material if it is tabled. I think it is appropriate on this occasion, and on subsequent occasions—as I say, I do not make this specific to Senator Newman—that further information be incorporated in the Hansard.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Family and Community Services (Senator Newman), to questions without notice asked today.

I want to concentrate my remarks in particular on the questions I asked of Senator Newman relating to the child-care services provided to our defence forces. The minister claimed to know nothing about the changes that are occurring in child-care services provided to the defence forces, and I accept that on face value. It is not her primary responsibility so that may well be the case. As I understand it, the defence forces have undertaken a program of contracting out, of privatising, the child-care services they provide to defence forces personnel and their families to a company called Kindergarten Union Services. This is part of a rationalisation of the child-care services provided to defence forces personnel and their families.

What I do know, from the information I have from clients of the child-care services and from the staff of the centres, is that, in addition to the privatisation measures, there will be fewer places available at defence forces child-care establishments. The centre I mentioned, in Swanbourne in my own state of Western Australia, is having its numbers cut from 47 to 28 places, and I understand there are similar reductions in services at other centres in Australia. I also know that the level of Commonwealth defence department subsidy to those establishments is being reduced and that the services have been told they will have to rely on less Defence Force subsidy. The impact of all this is that the capacity of these child-care centres to provide respite care and emergency care services is going to be reduced because they will be licensed for fewer places and they will have less staff.

As I understand it, the services currently provide care for children of families other than defence forces personnel to keep their numbers up. But what is of most concern to me—and it has been raised with me by the wife of a member of the defence forces—is that the capacity of these child-care centres to service the needs of families when troops are involved in action overseas will be diminished. The partner of the woman who wrote to me is currently on active service in Bougainville, and I understand there are a number of families of those currently serving in East Timor who are now seeking services from these centres.

There is a serious public policy issue here. As I said, I understand that originally child care was provided inside defence forces establishments not purely because of the transitory nature and the other demands of serving in the defence forces but also because of the need to assist families to respond to situations quickly. These are people who are often living away from family and friends in communities other than their normal communities. Obviously, when a partner is sent overseas on active service or is deployed in some other way, the strain on the family can be an unusual one and they require extra services.

The families of defence services personnel who have raised these concerns with me are concerned that these rationalisations will limit the capacity of defence services child-care services to meet the needs of the service families who are making such a huge commitment to our efforts in East Timor, in Bougainville and in other parts of the world where Australia has committed troops, either in advisory or in active duty roles. It is a very serious issue. I appreciate that the minister is going to come back to me, but I think there is a real concern that the government's broader child-care policies of reducing funding for child care, of reducing places, and of removing the priority of providing good quality child care in Australia is now being seen in the Defence Force as well. The contracting out of the service, the reduction in places and the reduction in funding are symptomatic of what has been happening in the general community, and now it is starting to affect Defence Force families, including the families of Defence Force personnel serving in East Timor and Bougainville. That is clearly not a desirable thing. We ought to be offering these families as much support as possible, but there is concern that these cutbacks in child care will impact on the families adversely.

talk.start.para: —Today we hear members on the other side talking about child care in general, and in particular about child care for Defence Force families. It often behoves us to go back in history to have a look at what happened when Labor was in government. I want to read out a notice of motion that Senator Newman gave on 2 May 1989. It reads:

speech.para: (i) late in 1988 the child care centre at RAAF Base Point Cook closed down through lack of funds,
(ii) both the Hamilton Report in 1986, and the Cross Report in 1988, pointed out the special need amongst service families for the provision of child care,
(iii) in April 1988, the then Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly) announced her intention of formulating child care policy guidelines before the August 1988 Budget,
(iv) no such guidelines were announced,
(v) the Children's Service Program which was announced in the 1988 Budget contained no specific provision for child care for Defence families, and

(vi) for 3 years the Federal Government has chosen to ignore the recommendations of the Hamilton Report, but has nevertheless sought to encourage employer-based child care in the public and private sectors by offering to fund 24 per cent of the running costs of 1000 centres, but no Defence Force centres; and

(b) condemns the Government's blatant hypocrisy on the issue of child care for Defence families, and calls on the Government to end its neglect to immediately adopting Cross Committee Recommendation 17 child care in its response to the Report on Personnel Wastage in the Australian Defence Force of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

They are hoist with their own petard. There is Labor's record summarised by Senator Newman—and they have the gall to get up here today and to talk about child-care facilities for people in the defence forces.

It helps to have a little look back through history and to remind the Labor Party of their record on child care. Their record was that child-care facilities were growing up around Australia inappropriately—in the wrong places, not necessarily based on need and out of control. There were no child-care facilities where they were needed in rural and regional areas, whereas child-care facilities were expanding in areas where there was not the same need.

The government's strong commitment to child care has been shown. We have spent in the order of $3 billion over the last three years—20 per cent more than Labor's last three years in office—and there will be an allocation of around $5.3 billion over four years to 2002-03, including an additional $600 million over three years from 2000 to 2001 with the introduction of the child-care benefit.

The opposition have made outrageous claims about child-care fee increases. Those claims have been exaggerated and based on the small but more expensive community sector. Contrary to Labor's claims, the community sector represents about only 30 per cent of children in long day care centres. As Senator Newman said in answer to a question to her today, fees are set by child-care operators, not by the government. In fact, the rate of fee increase for centres has halved under this government. It was increasing under Labor by 8.5 per cent per annum and it has been increasing under this government by four per cent per annum.

We also need to remind those opposite that the government contributes significantly to the child-care costs of low and middle income families. For low income families with two children in full-time care, the government assistance is around 75 per cent of the average fee in centres and around 80 per cent of the average fee in family day care. Families with children win under the coalition's policies in a number of ways. They win because we have a child-care policy which not only ensures that child care is being delivered in areas where it was not being delivered before but also takes into account the need for after school child care.

I remind honourable senators on the other side that, when they come in here and make the sorts of claims they do, it might just pay them to go back and have a little look at their record. I think the example I have given today of the treatment of the RAAF Base at Point Cook and the fact that child care in Defence Force centres was neglected under previous defence ministers—under Minister Kelly, for example—demonstrate that it is a case of the pot calling the kettle black with this opposition. They ought to look to themselves. They should find some policies of their own and get on with being an opposition. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak to the motion to take note of the responses by Minister Newman to questions she was asked during question time today. First of all, I would just like to note that the example that Senator Patterson gave us is, I understand, some 11 years old. Quite a bit of water has gone under the bridge since then.

speech.para: I wish to make some comment about the government's attitude to Australian women, especially women with children. Firstly, let us have a look at child care. Minister Newman, along with her Liberal colleagues, regularly trumpets the slogan of offering families more choice through the government's changes to child-care funding. With the removal of $850 million from the child-care budget, Australian women with children are not facing the choice of what sort of child care they may access but the choice of participating or not participating in the work force. I remember very clearly a parents' meeting in 1997 where women were discussing the impacts of the cuts in child care. A young mother of two children, on understanding how her family would be affected, came to the realisation that she simply could not afford her child-care expenses, and she said, `I don't think the Prime Minister wants me to work.' I think she was right.

Traditionally, women have more of a broken work pattern due to their child bearing commitments. But with less access to child- care support, women's work patterns will increasingly become more interrupted, impacting on women's career development and realisation of the potential for women's full participation in the work force. The arguments around choice in child care, according to the government's point of view, are in fact no choice at all.

I turn now to the impact on women of the leaked Kemp proposals on changes to higher education funding, especially the impact in regional areas. At James Cook University, based in Townsville and Cairns, 38.5 per cent of the undergraduate population is over 25 and, of these, 67 per cent are women. Women from regional and remote areas traditionally have taken up tertiary education later than those who come from the city areas. This is why the Kemp plan is going to be so damaging for regional universities and, in particular, women who attend them.

I ask: will a woman with children—and the inherent responsibilities that those children bring—a mortgage and other family commitments take the plunge and enrol at university in the knowledge that, at the end of that time, she will end up with a bill of $100,000 or more? I think that the answer is pretty clear: a woman with family responsibilities will be provided with another of the coalition's famous choices. Her choice, on the one hand, will be to undertake a university degree, with the laudable object of broadening her education and improving her employment options, but ending up with a loan at real interests rates adding up to some $100,000. On the other hand, her choice will simply be to not take up university study at all. There is no choice under the Kemp plan and there is no choice for women in rural Australia. Last week, Anne Harding, of the National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling, warned that higher tuition fees could affect home ownership patterns. Women will be very unlikely to take on a debt of $100,000 which could jeopardise their access in the future to home ownership.

These cuts in access to child care and the limiting of access to higher education options add to the list of changed policies which have affected women during the life of this govern ment. They add to the loss of 55 per cent of funds from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, which weakens the ability of women to deal with discrimination matters, both in a personal and a more general sense. They add to the cuts in funding to peak women's bodies that we heard about last week and the transfer from operational funding to project grants. Women can rightly question this government's views on their contribution to our community, and they will come up with the answer that this government does not care about women, especially women of child-bearing age.

talk.start.para: —I will briefly mention the government's record, Labor's failure and some of the background to Labor's claims that government is forcing families out of formal care. Finally, if I get the chance, I will address Senator McLucas's claims that the government is opposed to child care and has cut expenditure.

speech.para: The government has committed about $5.3 billion to child care up to the year 2000-03. By that year, expenditure is expected to reach about $1.5 billion annually. This expansion will provide about an additional 70,000 places. Child-care funding has been re-focused away from the nature of a centre, be it private or community-based, and onto the circumstances of the family. That was a deliberate policy. As Senator Patterson said before, the operational subsidy was focused on community-based centres, which supply only 28 per cent of child-care places. This meant that some 72 per cent of users failed to benefit from the assistance. Under Labor, the growth of child care went unchecked: there was no formal operational subsidy, there was no formal planning, resulting in oversupply in some areas and undersupply in others.

There are claims that the government is forcing families out of formal care, but there is no evidence to that effect. Child-care rebate figures show that the proportion of families claiming for informal care has fallen from eight to six per cent since its introduction in 1994. In fact, the number of children using child care has increased significantly from 460,000 in 1994-95 to over 544,000 in 1996-97.

Senator Patterson touched on the issue of quality in child care. Quality assurance is fundamentally important to this government in many areas, including child care. A review of the system of accreditation and quality improvement for long day care centres has been under way for some time in order to strengthen and improve its efficiency. This system has been acclaimed by many experts and governments of other countries. It was recently noted by the Australian Confederation of Childcare Centres that we should be proud of the standard and quality of our Australian services. Seventy-two per cent of long day care centres have undergone quality improvement and accreditation and have been granted the maximum three-year accreditation status. Quality assurance has been extended to family day care and outside school hours care, and that is critically important to this government.

The thesis of the motion to take note this afternoon is that the government is opposed to child care and has cut expenditure. The government's strong commitment to child care is demonstrated by several things: first of all, spending in the order of $3 billion in the last three years—20 per cent more than in Labor's last three years in office; secondly, with the introduction of the child-care benefit, the allocation of around $5.3 billion over four years to 2002-03, including an additional $600 million over three years from 2000 to 2001; finally, expenditure is expected to reach about $1.5 billion annually by 2002-03.

Senator McLucas made a point about access to higher education for rural men and women, in particular women. Senator Macdonald has touched on this important issue. As we heard when this matter was debated last week, the entire notion of tertiary education does not hinge on tertiary education fees per se; it hinges on how many places are available for tertiary education. This government has a very proud record in that it has drastically expanded the number of tertiary education places in this country. As far as the idea of $100,000 fees is concerned, the US voucher system has been repudiated by the Prime Minister, the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Senator Ellison. The government does not support it, but does support tertiary education fees along the HECS line that we currently have because that system has increased the number of places available, increased access and has made many more places available to men and women in rural and regional Australia.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak to the motion that the Senate take note of the answers given by Senator Newman on child care, particularly as they relate to the electorate of Bass. Recently I drew the chamber's attention to a problem a sole parent had in securing child care and the real possibility that that person would have her working hours reduced because options were not available to her. I related that to the situation in the north-west coast of Tasmania, where I live. Since then, the member for Bass, my colleague Michelle O'Byrne, has conducted a survey in her electorate, and this is what I want to focus on.

speech.para: The Minister often maintains that there has been no drop in funding for child care, yet seven out of the eight centres in Bass have certainly lost money, and I will list those and the percentages they have lost. I have the results of the survey here, and I will go through some of the other issues later. I also want to put on record that this is an authentic survey and the responses have been collated and produced in a document.

The Stewart Street child-care centre lost over 11 per cent; the Dame Marjorie Parker centre lost 36 per cent; the Bungawitta Child Care Centre lost 49 per cent; the Children's Playhouse lost 32 per cent; the Pedder Patter lost 51 per cent; the Tasmanian university lost over 45 per cent; and the Watchorn Street centre lost 52 per cent. There was only one place with an increase: Gordon Square centre received an increase of just over $16,000. The statistics that were contained in the question that I asked Senator Newman this afternoon were from that survey and from the department.

Senator Newman and the government need to be aware that in quite a number of cases child care is now costing more than a private school for children in first year. I know that is true because my niece sends her children to a private school down south, out of Hobart, because it is cheaper than putting them in child care.

The Howard government's reason for abolishing the operational subsidy was an attempt to force community based centres to become competitive with private centres which did not receive an operational subsidy. The private centres claimed that it was not a level playing field and they were forced to charge higher fees in order to be viable. As a result, they were not considered competitive within the industry. While this is logical, it is not the case in Tasmania. We have made that point time and time again. Tasmania is not in line with mainland states and therefore this sort of logic—or otherwise—does not apply to Tasmania. In the north-east, where the member for Bass did her survey, there are eight centres with only three private centres operating. Therefore, parents do have problems and not a lot of choices.

I will go through some of the questions that were asked in the survey and the responses that were received. One of the questions was what the average number of days per week was that you used a child-care centre. The response was 3.5. The average cost to the family was $118 per week. Tasmania is a depressed economy—and I think Senator Newman made mention of that—so those sorts of amounts of money are difficult for some Tasmanian families to access. The response for the average number of children in child care was 1.5. The number of centres surveyed in that survey was four. We need to look very carefully at this issue, particularly in Tasmania. Sixty-nine per cent of the people who responded said that they used alternative forms of child care. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on this motion proposed by Senator Evans to take note of the answer from Minister Newman on child care. Senator Evans's question specifically referred to supposed cuts in child-care centres serving defence families. However, he conceded that there may not be any cuts because the cuts may reflect actual demand, but he still has concern generally in view of the government's broader policy of reduced child care. That particular statement is incorrect. The government has a very strong commitment to improving child care.

speech.para: Senator Patterson, in response to Senator Evans's argument, raised the dismal record of the former Labor government in the way they dealt with provision of child care facilities, particularly in relation to the needs of defence families. I do not wish to dwell too much on the record of the previous Labor government because to argue that we start from a low base is not a productive argument. There is no point in debating how badly the community was served by the previous government. Rather, we should look at how this government is serving the community better.

Senator McLucas made the throwaway comment that Senator Patterson's information seemed to be quite a few years out of date and that a lot of water had gone under the bridge. She is precisely right—a lot of water has gone under the bridge since the Labor government departed. In the last three years, the Howard government has increased spending in the child-care area by up to $3 billion, which is 20 per cent up on the Labor government record in the last three years they were in government. So there is no question that we have cut spending at all; we have actually increased spending substantially.

It is important to note that the government's policy in the child-care area is not limited to throwing money at the issues. Apart from increasing spending, the Howard government has also focused on increasing the possibility of choices for families. This comes in the form of the introduction of child-care benefits, so that the money goes directly to the family and they can have the choice of the type of child care that they wish to put their children in. The allocation of the child-care benefit will be around $5.3 billion over four years from this year onwards, including an additional $6 million over three years from 2000-01.

Another element in the government's policy is the increase in real support for low and middle income families, because it is the low income and middle income families which have real need for child-care support. For low income families with two children in full-time care, the government assistance is around 75 per cent of the average fee in centres, and the figure is around 80 per cent of average fees in family day care centres.

The fourth element of this government's initiative, which the Labor government in their 13 years never addressed, is to improve quality assurance. As Senator Mason mentioned, 72 per cent of long day care centres now have been granted accreditation status for three years. This is something desperately important. It is not just a case of providing money for child-care centres; it is important that the child-care centre actually operates and provides services to the children in its care. It is not just a matter of counting the number of children or the amounts of money spent per child; it is the quality of care that is the most important thing. (Time expired)

para.inline: EQUAL OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN IN THE WORKPLACE AMENDMENT BILL 1999

speech.para: To amend the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986 as follows:

. adopt the following title and terms: the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Act 1999, the Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace Agency, and the Director of Equal Opportunity for Women in the Workplace;
. insert an objects clause;
. provide for reporting to be done biennially, rather than annually as at present;
. provide an expanded system of waiving the reporting requirement for specified periods of time for organisations that satisfy particular criteria; and

. replace the requirement for reporting on specified steps with a requirement for reporting focused on outcomes, based on actions taken to eliminate discrimination and promote equal employment opportunity.

The Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act 1986 was reviewed in 1997-98 as one of a number of scheduled legislative reviews implementing the Government's commitment to the 1995 Competition Principles Agreement.
This Bill implements the Government's response to the recommendations made by the independent review committee.

The Bill will reduce the regulatory burden which the legislation currently places upon business and at the same time better ensure equal opportunity for working women. For this reason, the Bill is an important measure in meeting the Government's election commitments to the business community and to women, and should be progressed without delay.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business)

The Bill will allow domestic law effect to be given to double taxation agreements with South Africa, Slovakia and Argentina, and an Amending Protocol to our existing double taxation agreement with Malaysia.

The double taxation agreement with South Africa was signed on 1 July 1999 and the Amending Protocol to the double taxation agreement with Malaysia on 2 August 1999, the double taxation agreement with Slovakia was signed on 24 August 1999, and the double taxation agreement with Argentina was signed on 27 August 1999. Failure to have introduction and passage, followed by royal assent, exchange of Notes and entry into force of the respective treaties by 31 December 1999 will mean that the treaties will not be able to take effect in domestic law in January/July 2000 (ie. at the earliest possible dates) but will be delayed for a full calendar year until January/July 2001, to the detriment of affected taxpayers.
Result if Bill not dealt with in these sittings :

There will be a one year delay in the treaties coming into domestic law effect, to the detriment of those who have, for example, invested abroad and who will benefit from reduced withholding taxes in those countries. In the case of the Malaysian Protocol, Australian taxpayers will continue to suffer unrelieved double taxation for a further year in respect of fees for technical services they receive from Malaysia.
(Circulated by authority of the Treasurer)
The principal purposes of the proposed Bill are:

. to enable nominated members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal (the AAT) to continue to issue warrants authorising Commonwealth and State law enforcement agencies to intercept telecommunications and Commonwealth law enforcement agencies to use listening devices; and
. to include the Anti-Corruption Commission of WA (ACC) and the Crime Commission of Qld (QCC) as intercepting agencies.

para.inline: Reasons for seeking Introduction and passage in the same sittings

speech.para: The provisions enabling nominated members of the AAT to issue interception and listening device warrants are subject to a sunset clause (s.3 of the Telecommunications (Interception) and Listening Device Amendment Act 1997) which terminates the power of nominated AAT members to issue warrants at the end of 1999.

The administrative function of issuing warrants cannot be conferred on judges of the Federal or Family Courts without their consent. Most judges have withdrawn their consents because they consider the function is incompatible with their judicial duties. There has been no indication that the federal judges are likely to change their views. Therefore, if the provisions conferring warrant-issuing powers on nominated AAT members are allowed to expire, there will be no authority available to issue interception and listening device warrants. This will seriously impede the ability of police and other law enforcement agencies to deal with major crime, particularly offences involving the importation and trafficking in prohibited drugs. This outcome would also be likely to have an adverse impact on Commonwealth-State relations.

The ACC was established by the Anti-Corruption Commission Act 1988 (WA). It deals with corruption, crime and serious improper conduct by "public officers". The WA Government is particularly concerned about police corruption in that State and wants the ACC to have full interception powers as soon as possible. The QCC was established under the Crime Commission Act 1997 (Qld). It has a responsibility to investigate criminal paedophilia and organised crime. Similarly to WA, the Queensland Government urgently wants the new Crime Commission to be fully equipped with appropriate powers to fight organised crime in that State.
(Circulated by authority of the Attorney-General)

Dear Senator
Thank you for your letter of 26 August 1999 concerning my Determination No. 1/1999 under the Student Assistance Act 1973.

You have asked for clarification as to whether the typographical error in the revoked Determination No 2/1998 or the retrospective application of Determination 1/1999, which I made to correct the error, operate to the disadvantage of any person.

By way of background, the Education Minister's Determination of education institutions and secondary and tertiary courses under the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 was used, up until 30 June 1998, to specify courses that students were required to be undertaking to be eligible for Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs AUSTUDY payments delivered through Centrelink. The AUSTUDY scheme was replaced, from 1 July 1998 by the Youth Allowance, Austudy, and Pensioner Education Supplement payments. While these payments are administered by the Department of Family and Communications,unity Services, continuity of financial assistance to students was maintained as these payments are also delivered through Centrelink.

To coincide with this change, the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 was amended to become the Student Assistance Act 1973 and a new Determination (2/1998) was made under this Act with effect from 1 July 1998. This Student Assistance Act Determination is referred to in the Social Security Act 1991 to identify courses that students must be undertaking to be eligible for the Youth Allowance or Austudy as full time students and to identify courses that certain pensioners and allowees must be undertaking to be eligible for the Pensioner Education Supplement. The Determination is also referred to in my policy guidelines to identify courses for the payment of ABSTUDY and the ABSTUDY Pensioner Education Supplement.

The new Determination 2/1998 was not intended to change the coverage of courses approved for student assistance as previously provided for under AUSTUDY. On close inspection, however, it was discovered that the definition of "higher education institution" and the definition of "non-government higher education institution" in the Determination were in error. They referred to "paragraphs 34(3)(b)-(h) (inclusive)" of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 where they should have referred to paragraphs 34(4)(b)-(h) (inclusive) of that Act to maintain coverage of the Australian Defence Force Academy, the National Institute of Dramatic Art, and the Australian Film Television and Radio School.

The intention of the reference was clear, and payments of student assistance to students continued as if the typographical error in the reference to the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 had not been made in Determination 2/1988.

The error in the reference did not result in the inclusion of any additional education institutions under the Determination or the payment of income support to students in courses contrary to Government policy.
The retrospective application of my Determination 1/1999, correcting the error from the date of effect of Determination 2/1988, is beneficial and there will be no losers under the new Determination.
Yours sincerely
(Sgd) DAVID KEMP
