Now, we are prepared to give it a go—obviously the issues in regional and rural Australia are really critical—but we do object to not just money for the boys and girls in relation to the continuing and exponential growth in discretionary funding by this government, but also jobs for the boys and girls without adequate parliamentary scrutiny. I wonder whether in fact the lessons in Victoria have been learnt by this federal government, and I hope they have. I wonder whether the actions of the former Premier of Victoria, Mr Jeff Kennett, have been adequately scrutinised by this government. If they had been, I think that we would have seen an about-face in the way that these types of programs are handled because the public these days is simply not prepared to allow this type of thing to go on unchecked.

We have seen the untrammelled use of commercial-in-confidence as a way of obfuscation and hiding information by this government, something which I know that a number of people, including the Clerk of the Senate, have a great deal of interest in. We have seen two senior ministers dodging, ducking and diving in relation to the Federation Fund money and what went on in relation to that. We have had the real agenda on higher education revealed by the leaked cabinet submission, with the total and complete humiliation today of Dr Kemp in relation to that. We have already had Minister Reith's great vision for Australia, which was leaked earlier this year, and the one yet to come, of course, is the secret document of Senator Newman which she has refused to provide to the Senate.

Just to get back briefly to the issue, what we have here is a situation where the minister wishes to appropriate an additional $50 million to non-redundancy funds, something that the industry by and large does not want. In the committee hearing we asked the two major stevedores how much of those funds they would in fact be interested in accessing. P&O said nothing and Patrick's said $1 million—that is out of $50 million. So one wonders where the rest of the money is going to go and one cannot help but believe that in fact it may be more slush funds for the government. That is something that we will not tolerate and we will be moving amendments to the contrary.

Essentially our amendments, which will be moved by Senator O'Brien on behalf of the opposition and, as I understand, will be supported by the Democrats, are aimed at introducing some transparency and accountability into this bill and some capacity for parliamentary scrutiny in relation to this bill. Hopefully, they will start a trend into the future of ensuring that we do not hide behind the use of commercial-in-confidence, we do not have our mates on references committees making recommendations direct to the minister without any capacity for the parliament to scrutinise them, and we do not have a situation whereby we get FOI claims with huge black ink all over them and it requires papertrails of many, many weeks in order to track precisely where the funding has gone. This government has made an artform of obfuscation and it has made an artform of ensuring that the process is not transparent but as opaque as possible, and I think that the amendments to be moved by Senator O'Brien will, in one small way, go towards ensuring that this type of unacceptable behaviour is stopped.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being nearly 9.50 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to talk about a new concept, the one of cyberdemocracy. The exponential growth of the Internet as the world's largest electronic network, now connecting over 100 million people in more than 130 countries, and its subsequent economic impact have not gone unremarked upon in this place. What has not received as much attention is the potential for the Internet to change the way that we politicians interact with members of the community, and they with us. The potential for the Internet to impact upon the parliamentary process has been described in varying terms, such as `cyberdemocracy' through to `an electronic republic'. This latter concept has been developed by Lawrence K. Grossman in his book aptly titled The Electronic Republic :

speech.para: This is the first generation of citizens who can see, hear, and judge their own political leaders simultaneously and instantaneously. It is also the first generation of political leaders who can address the entire population and receive instant feedback about what the people think and want. Interactive telecommunications increasingly give ordinary citizens immediate access to the major political decisions that affect their lives and properties.

The Internet has already gained political significance as increasing numbers in the community use it to learn about government policies and actions and to contact elected representatives. In contrast to other communication mediums such as the familiar ones of radio, television and print, the Internet replaces the simple sender-receiver model of communication with a more interactive approach, allowing ideas to be challenged rather than merely accepted. The ability for people to log on and both send and receive information from the comfort of their own homes increases their access to information and, consequently, their potential influence over government, organisations and other Net users.

The use of the Net in the political sphere has dramatically altered the relationship between politicians and their constituents, in particular in relation to the speed of communications between them. The growth of the medium has been witnessed, I am sure, by all my colleagues in their electorate offices during the lead-up to the INTERFET troops entering East Timor. Prior to that time I had received, I suppose, a few dozen phone calls and faxes, but emails virtually in the hundreds came in calling for action. Just a couple of years ago, the number of phone calls and faxes would have far outnumbered email messages. Likewise, unlike five years ago, members of the public can now gain vast amounts of information about departments and government agencies without having to speak personally to one of their representatives.

Many of the coalition's recent initiatives for regional Australia have been focused on the provision of government services via the Internet, making government information more accessible for those people living in rural and remote areas. No longer is it necessary for people to travel very long distances during office hours to ensure they get the assistance they need. The Internet is changing the way that politicians and their staff interact with the community and is making this communication both speedier and more efficient.

The use of the Internet has also become an essential tool of political campaigning, although it may be said that Australian political parties have not yet fully explored the possibilities offered by it. In recent years, politicians have come under fire from the public for being out of touch and aloof from their constituents and for failing to listen to the electorate's concerns. If we are to reverse this current trend in popular thinking and revitalise the public's faith in our parliamentary system, the opportunities posed by the net should be seized by us all.

In an electronic democracy, individual citizens would be empowered to communicate directly with leaders, express their opinions, ask questions and, ultimately, make their own judgments about laws, policies and affairs of state. But there are some disadvantages. While there is not much doubt that the net and access to elected representatives offer the Australian community new possibilities for political learning and action, there are some dangers in simultaneous and instantaneous opinion making. Significantly, there is the risk that our current system of representative government, whereby elected officials in a representative capacity act on behalf of their constituents, may be replaced by direct democracy where individuals have what could be called `a seat at the table' of the government.

You might ask: what is wrong with that? Potentially, there would then be the risk that populism could dictate government thinking and decisions when, in fact, sound policy based on reflection and formulated for the majority in the national interest is what the country needs. Allowing a direct vote for particular measures may be no better than following knee-jerk public opinion polls. As Wendy Lewis, author of the article `Digital Democracy: Restoring Citizens' Trust' and creator of The Civic Mind web site, has written:

If every issue were put to a vote of the people, decision making would become no more than instant poll taking, with all of the negative consequences of any snap judgment. Unlike direct democracy, representative democracy ensures free and fair debate, taking into account the widely disparate needs of a diverse society. In contrast, relying on cyberpolls could easily lead to decision making that fosters governance by minority.
There is no doubt that majority views can also go off the track but, by and large, our system of checks and balances does allow for proper consideration and a balanced view.

There is also a problem in that the Internet could be controlled, I suppose, by elite groups. The ability for the net to make parliamentary democracy more representative is somewhat perversely limited by its very availability to us all. There is the real risk that knowledge of how to use the net may be concentrated with some and not others. The technologically poor or disadvantaged within the community may be excluded from access because of financial costs or lack of information, skills or know-how. The government is helping to counteract this possibility with the funding that it provides for various Internet schemes across the country. Politics on the net may be as trivialised as it is in other media. As is beginning to be seen in the United States, the potential exists for commercial interests to control the web in a manner similar to the control that is presently exerted over other mass media.
In his introduction to Media, Culture and Society, which examines electronic democracy, editor Colin Sparks comments:
The problem is that technical changes which have made opposition easier have also further empowered the already powerful.

He goes on to explain that, because the technology is available both to those who would oppose and to those who are already powerful, technological change `does not shift the balance of forces either for or against democratisation'. Sparks argues that, as minority groups do not have the ability to gain more or better access than elite groups, democracy is not necessarily enhanced by the web—which is an interesting viewpoint.

So what is the way forward here? Despite these concerns, the imminence of an electronic republic requires that it be dealt with now. It is time that all members of parliament acknowledged the significant part that the Internet will play in creating new forms of participation between the community and its elected representatives. Online political participation will only increase as a computer savvy younger generation grow up and log on to learn more about their government and politicians. We must consider how we can best provide information to the public and properly inform public opinion.

In mid-November I will be joining other parliamentary colleagues by establishing a web page that will, I hope, be interactive and meaningful. My web page will include poll questions, a questionnaire to gain public opinion on various issues, links to valuable sites, a posting board where I can contact constituents directly online, as well as the usual information about the government and my parliamentary role. I will also be including a youth survey and a youth issues page—developed by our 16-year-old work experience student, Catherine Lister, who comes from PLC at Pymble—to foster greater participation by youth, who are turning to the web in droves to gain information.

The Internet is a valuable way to connect with our nation's youth and to exchange information on issues that will be important for future generations of Australians. While digital democracy is a new and emerging form of political participation, by itself it is not a substitute for our current system of government. However, it is an essential tool for reconnecting the community and the government in a way that builds both trust and accountability.

talk.start.para: —It appears that shortly everyone will be stampeding to have their own web page on the Internet, and I too eventually will have to join that crowd.

speech.para: I will turn to the issue which I would like to inform the Senate about tonight. I noticed a special report in the Queensland Country Life, headed `Uncertainty surrounds levies'. Written by Graham Fuller and published on 7 October, the article states:
Growing uncertainty surrounds State Government plans to dispense with the statutory arrangements that currently apply to Queensland's peak producer bodies.

Proposed changes to the present system of compulsory primary producer bodies, currently representing cane growers, dairy farmers, fruit and vegetable growers, pork producers and commercial fishermen, probably will result in them no longer being able to collect levies from their members.
Instead, funding will come from voluntary membership fees.

Strange goings-on seem to be occurring in country Queensland. It seems that the Queensland Canegrowers, a hard-nosed bunch of farming zealots, have more in common with New South Wales labour unions than might rightly be expected. At the recent NSW State Labor Conference, the NSW Labor Council outlined its proposal to seek legislative backing for a new system in workplace agreements. Basically, the system, as I understand it, is a corollary of enterprise bargaining.
As reported by Nina Field in the Financial Review on 8 October 1999, Michael Costa explained:
It is about removing the ability of non-union members to "free ride" by benefiting from union negotiated pay increases.

The article goes on to explain that it is resource intensive for unions to enterprise bargain on behalf of members. This idea got a run in Workers Online in June 1999. In that publication, David Chin, a solicitor at Jones Staff, contributed an articled entitled `A fair case for free-rider laws'. In essence, paraphrasing his argument, he said, `The proposal to enable unions to charge non-members a service fee for negotiating enterprise agreements is consistent with the principle of freedom of association. The article went on to say that the proposal, in a nutshell, `involves enabling union negotiated enterprise agreements to contain a clause in the negotiated agreement which provides for non-union members who are covered by the agreement and receive the increased wages and benefits of the agreement to pay fees at the same level as a contribution for union members during the term of the agreement'.

The agreement, of course, would be voted on and would need the support of a majority of employees and the concurrence of the employer. Free riding is not stood for in the business world; in fact, the RACQ does not provide a service for non-members. Similarly, the cane growers, as I have quoted from their special report, do not like free riders in the system either. The proposal does not require workers to join a union. It simply requires these workers to pay for a service, as I understand it, that they benefit from in the way of higher wages or improved conditions, and they have been given the ability to vote as well. In addition, unions have a responsibility under the present system to maintain the award system and fulfil their obligations that the legislation places upon them. Enterprise bargaining has increased those obligations and, as a consequence, financial burdens have also increased. A more equitable regime seems inevitable, as the current system effectively entrenches free riders in the system. Unions, it seems, accept the obligation to bargain on behalf of all workers, including non-members, and to sign off on agreements for all workers at a workplace. No account is factored in for free riders—non-members who are happy to have a union bargain on their behalf but who do not particularly want to be obliged to join.

The present legislation does not permit the union bargaining to be restricted to unions only, nor should it. This would be quite discriminatory. Notwithstanding, many employers have adopted this practice of encouraging some employees into individual contracts while leaving some who do not agree with the ideology of the company to remain on lower rates of pay. The idea is not new. That good old free enterprise country of the world, the USA, uses it. Canada uses it—they call it the Rand clause. If Mr Reith is so wedded to the market, perhaps he should stop worrying about unions and accept change. Mr Reith, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, could hardly contain himself. He jumped the gun and put out a press statement headed `Non-union workers forced to pay into union/ALP slush fund', in September 1999. Obviously, the Hon. Peter Reith failed to comprehend the actual policy proposal. But that is not surprising. He also apparently failed to consult with the National Party.

However, enough about this: let us go back to why it is so relevant to the Queensland Canegrowers Council. In a recent special report, as I have mentioned, in Queensland Country Life, Ian Ballantyne, the general manager of the cane growers, stated in the article:
. . . the key issue at stake is the right of every cane grower to be represented. The organisation is especially concerned about even small numbers of growers opting to become `free riders,'—
the term crops up again—
thereby reducing Canegrowers' voice and capacity to represent and service the whole industry.
Mr Ian Ballantyne went on to say:
The strength of our organisation has always been grower unity, 100 per cent membership and a mandatory levy system.
Mr Graham Cossart, a cane grower in the Bundaberg area, chipped in in the same article:

Our organisation, Canegrowers, has served us well for about 75 years and I can't see any reason for the statutory levy system to be abolished. Even though it's compulsory, I don't have a problem with the concept.
Farmers like me aren't into agri-politics and we rely on Canegrowers to lobby the government for us on a whole range of issues.

In addition, the Canegrowers Council appears in the commission and argues against wage increases for workers and suchlike. Maybe Mr Reith should be checking his own backyard first. I guess the debate about this issue is far from over. However, it does seem that when you place unions and cane growers together, they have more in common than you might otherwise expect.

talk.start.para: —Last week a letter was sent to my office from three Australian Falun Gong practitioners. It concerned the death of a Falun Gong practitioner in China, Ms Zhao. This is a little of what was said in that letter:

speech.para: We feel deeply grieved for the death of Ms Zhao. What is more alarming was the fact that she was tortured to death simply because she was not willing to stop practising Falun Gong. We have been trying our best to draw worldwide attention to the torture of Falun Gong practitioners in China so as to avoid this tragic event happening. Unfortunately, it did happen.
The letter also refers to an article on the Internet, outlining the details of Ms Zhao's death. The article reads, in part:

On Sept. 27, 1999, Ms. Zhao was taken away by the Zhangxing County police when she was working in the farm fields. The police asked her if she would continue to practice Falun Gong. She said "yes", and they started to torture her. She lost consciousness in the morning on Oct. 7 and was to sent to the county hospital for emergency recovery. After she regained consciousness she was taken back by the police and tortured again until 3 PM. She died before arriving in the hospital.

She was tortured at least with police electric clubs and rubber clubs, and electrified with old-style rotary telephones. The police repeatedly asked if she would continue to practice Falun Gong, and she always answered with "yes". Her skin was broken all over her body except on her face".

That is the end of the quote. An autopsy report apparently concluded that Ms Zhao had died through a beating with blunt objects. My office has been sent many reports and photos of people apparently arrested and tortured over recent weeks, allegedly because they are Falun Gong practitioners. To date, it seems that there has been limited independent verification of these stories. But the reports are uncomfortably similar to each other and to other verified practices undertaken by Chinese authorities in the past.

So, what is Falun Gong? Falun Gong, also known as Falun Dafa, is a meditation system. In the words of its practitioners, it is an `ancient cultivation system of improving one's mind and body.' It has its origins in Qhigong, but focuses on `Gong' cultivation of energy rather than `Qhi'. Mr Li Hongzhi, the leader of the movement, first introduced the system to China in 1992. The aim of the system is to cultivate one's heart, mind and inner nature. Basically, the benefits aimed for are reduced stress levels, peace of mind and enhanced health and energy levels. The main principles of the teaching are upholding virtues, forbearance, dealing with losses and gains equally, and rectifying unhealthy habits.

It is estimated that more than 100 million people in 30 countries practice Falun Gong. The Falun Gong practitioners have conducted a survey to determine the health effects of the system. In short, they found that 80 per cent of practitioners reported an improvement in physical health and 96 per cent reported an improvement in mental health.

On July 22 this year, however, the Chinese Ministry of Civil Affairs denounced Falun Gong as an illegal organisation, and practitioners were banned from practising in public or in private. Amnesty International reports that this is just a new example of the Chinese authorities' tactic of `harassing, detaining or criminalising citizens who are peacefully exercising basic human rights.' Others liken it to the anti-rightist campaign in 1957, the Great Leap Forward in 1958-60, the Cultural Revolution in 1966-76, or the campaign to eliminate spiritual pollution in 1983 and 1984. This campaign has similar overtones. The Chinese media is rife with unbelievable re-education stories, and people denouncing the practitioners and discrediting stories from the international media. As well, pressure is put on practitioners through employment, housing and pensions.

Originally, the founder, Li Hongzhi, registered Falun Gong with the Qigong Research Association of China. Qigong is a popular method of breathing and exercise. However, after disagreement about the foundations of Qigong, Li Hongzhi withdrew the movement from the Qigong Research Association of China, thereby removing the official recognition.

Prior to its banning, Falun Gong was not registered anywhere and it was not recognised as a legitimate body. Therefore it had no legal protection and no legal status. When the Chinese government banned Falun Gong, authorities proceeded to arrest hundreds of practitioners. According to a Hong Kong human rights group, 300 people were arrested in cities around the country, and I have unconfirmed reports from Australian practitioners that this number is now much, much higher.

The Chinese government then embarked on a concerted effort to discredit the movement. Part of this was the media reports which went to great lengths to outline the insidiousness of the movement and the falseness of its leader. The Chinese government has also tried to extradite Mr Li Hongzhi from the USA, where he currently resides. The USA has refused on the grounds of religious freedom. To aid his case, President Ziang Zemin recently gave President Clinton a book with photos of practitioners who had allegedly killed themselves in macabre ways because of their superstitious beliefs. The book, however, did not convince President Clinton that Falun Gong should be stamped out.
It is not clear why the Chinese government has banned this religious movement. According to the Beijing Review, it is because:

. . . it was not registered by law, it had engaged in illegal activities, advocating superstition and spreading fallacies, hoodwinking people, inciting and creating disturbances and jeopardising social stability.
The Chinese Vice Minister of Civil Affairs, Li Baoku, said in August this year:

In recent years, Falun Gong organisations have instigated and hoodwinked their followers in various places to harass and besiege Party and government departments and media institutions. They have also organised a number of large scale illegal gatherings.
They apparently harassed and besieged the party through silent meditation, because that is what they do most.

In 1981, the UN General Assembly adopted the Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and Discrimination Based on Religion or Belief. In July, Mr Wu Zhongze, Director of the Non-government Organisation Management Bureau under the Ministry of Civil Affairs, told a press conference that China's constitution protects the freedom of religious belief and normal religious activities. And that is true. Article 36 of the Chinese constitution says:
Citizens of the People's Republic of China enjoy freedom of religious belief.

No state organ, public organization or individual may compel citizens to believe in, or not to believe in, any religion; nor may they discriminate against citizens who believe in or do not believe in, any religion.
Unfortunately, that does not seem to be happening here.

Mr Wu pointed out at the press conference that the Regulations on the Registration and Management of Mass Organisations stipulate that mass organisations should be registered and their activities should abide by the constitution, the laws, the regulations and the policies of the country. The organisations should not violate fundamental principles of the constitution or jeopardise interests of the nation or the people, nor should they jeopardise the interests of other organisations and citizens. However, according to Mr Wu, Falun Gong had been engaged in unlawful activities, advocating superstition, spreading fallacies, hoodwinking people, inciting and creating disturbances, and jeopardising social stability. That of course would include gathering in parks to practice movements together and to meditate.

One of the worrying things about China claiming that they subscribe to religious freedom is that they in fact have a history of religious intolerance, of arbitrary detention and torture. Falun Gong is not alone in being targeted by the Chinese authorities. Amnesty International reports:

A nationwide "anti superstition" campaign which has been in progress since at least mid 1998. The official media has repeatedly denounced traditional practices such as feng shui—geomancy, and fortune telling. "Unauthorised" temples have been demolished, and adherents of charismatic or unorthodox religious and millenarian groups have been assigned without trial to re-education through labour camps. Their alleged leaders have also been sentenced to death or long prison terms for allegedly defrauding followers, "organising cults to obstruct the implementation of the law" or duping female followers into sex as a "sacred summons," which is considered rape."

The penalty for subversion is death, so the consequences of claiming the right to practise Falun Gong can be severe. I am also concerned that the practitioners have free and fair trials. I consider that, given the current cli mate of fear and misinformation, that would be impossible without international monitors.

The current situation is terrible. These people must be able to practise any form of meditation. There is no threat to national security. They practise together in parks and public spaces because they consider it enhances their energy. It is not to subvert any social order. I urge the Australian government to pressure the Chinese government, through all available avenues, to: firstly, reassess the status of Falun Gong and to recognise it for what it is—a peaceful, non-political meditation movement; secondly, allow independent observers in to monitor the condition of prisoners in the gaols; and, finally, monitor trials of these prisoners to ensure that those trials are legal and fair.

talk.start.para: —As you would be aware, Madam President, I am a rare speaker on the adjournment, but this is the first opportunity I have had to put on the record a matter that has concerned me for some time. In fact, it goes back to when I had the pleasure of leading a bipartisan delegation to Taiwan in July, at the invitation of the Taipei economic and cultural office. I note that Senator Conroy, who was one of the members of our delegation, is in the chamber tonight. As well as other matters, we discussed business prospects in Australia, and we had the opportunity to view some business organisations in Taiwan. Since returning, they have had an horrific earthquake, and I want to reiterate how much sympathy the Australian parliament has for Taiwan, which has suffered horrific loss of life as a result of that earthquake.

speech.para: Madam Deputy President, you may recall that, on many occasions, I and my colleagues in this place have raised the question of the Parkville Piggery that was owned by the former Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Of course, we all saw it on the 60 Minutes program. I think Mr Achilles Constantinides became a family name there for a while with the exposure he was getting in the media. The piggery was sold to Indonesian interests—the Soeryadjaya family. Since then we have had the situation where the Attorney-General, Mr Williams, has decided to take no further action about the matter.

But what I want to talk about are the unintended consequences of the publicity that that operation received and the effect that publicity has had on a joint venture group in Taiwan who bought this business from the Indonesians. The consortium consists of the Taiwan Sugar Corporation, the China Development Bank, Steff Houlberg—a Danish partner—and ESS Food. Senator Conroy was approached by Mr Benny Hu, one of the directors of the China Development Bank and well known outside of Taiwan as an entrepreneur and investor for the Taiwan government, because they were having problems raising finance in Australia purely and simply because of the publicity about what had been happening with the Parkville Piggery. That was having an effect on their chances of raising money.

What the consortium propose with this piggery and other ventures is quite exciting news for Australia. One of the things that we as members of the Australia-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group have been trying to do for some time has been to get Taiwan to invest some money in Australia in large investments, because we see Australia as a very safe place to invest. The Taiwan Sugar Corporation have been quite a large investor in Australia, as most people would know—and as I am sure Senator Boswell knows. They are the largest state owned agribusiness company in Taiwan. They are one of the leaders in pig raising technology in Taiwan. They produce something like 500,000 pigs a year, and they have a turnover of over $US1 billion. So they are quite a significant corporation.

Their partner, the China Development Bank, are one of the most experienced and largest investment companies in Taiwan. They have 56 per cent of the market share and over 250 investors. They went into partnership with a Danish partner, Steff Houlberg. They are the second largest slaughterhouse group in Denmark. Using leading technology, they slaughter something like 2.7 million pigs a year, and their turnover is $US850 million. Another partner in the consortium is ESS Food, the largest distribution company in Denmark—selling 324,000 tonnes of pork worldwide. Their turnover is $US1.4 billion. So we are talking about four companies that, you would have to say, are large players by any means.

They purchased the Parkville Piggery, and one of the first matters that confronted them was the existing environmental problem that we all know about—a very large smell. I suppose Senator Heffernan, who is sitting in front of me, would probably confirm that there has been a stink around this piggery for many years. But in this particular case we are talking about a real environmental problem that has been identified. The Taiwanese group indicated to us in the delegation that they were going to spend something like $A3 million to combat that problem and reduce the odour levels that have been identified as level 6—but six out of what I do not know. Level 3 is acceptable, but they want to reduce the level down to level 1 or 2. So, obviously, the efforts they are making are quite significant. They expect to have that completed by April 2000.

They propose to use the Parkville Piggery that they purchased from the Indonesians who purchased it from Mr Keating as a breeding sow establishment. They propose to build a new advanced pig slaughterhouse in Queensland—a huge operation. They want to build, own and operate that particular slaughterhouse. It will have a maximum slaughterhouse capacity of something like 600,000 pigs a year and will employ something like 600 Australians, which is quite significant in job terms. It would be a very modern, intensive piggery. They are proposing to have 21,000-odd sows in four stages which, over a period of time, will produce approximately 450,000 pigs a year. It would certainly be a state-of-the-art establishment. Very importantly, they expect to export 80 per cent of that product to Japan.

Being a good Tasmanian, I did ask the representatives of the consortium why they would want to set up in Queensland when they could find a very good place in Tasmania—I am sure we could find somewhere in Tasmania to set up a piggery to employ 600 people. They explained to me that, if you were going to export into Japan, the pork has to be produced in tropical conditions to get the right sort of flavour to appeal to the taste of the Japanese. So under those conditions—and being, I suppose, a senator of Australia—I have to go along with what they want to do.

I take this opportunity tonight to place on the record that time has passed on. Regardless of what has been said about Mr Keating and the former piggery, the opportunity is there now for Taiwanese interests, along with Australian joint ventures, to develop a massive export industry into Japan. I implore those investors and banks who have been rather loath to invest in this development because of the fear of publicity in the media to think of the big picture rather than what has happened before. I commend to the Senate and to Australia the proposed venture by the Taiwanese in Queensland which will provide quite significant numbers of jobs. I hope that my colleague Senator Conroy would support my comments here tonight.

talk.start.para: —I rise in complete support of Senator Calvert and his contribution. As he has indicated, the piggery has had a very colourful past over the last few years. While the hurly-burly of politics is just that, and lots of things get said in this chamber by all sides, this is a situation where the national interest has moved on. I would like to congratulate Senator Calvert in recognising that and in recognising a unique opportunity. Certainly, following the indication from his colleagues, we want to see the establishment of this piggery as soon as is possible.

speech.para: This is a unique opportunity, as Senator Calvert has said, for Australian jobs, Australian dollars and Australian exports. We have moved beyond the arguments of the past; a line has been drawn in the sand. I rise today to share with Senator Calvert, and to pass on to anybody who can see a good opportunity, the view that the debate over the piggery is finished. We now have new owners who have assessed this project as a real winner. If companies have been reticent to be involved in this new project, then Senator Calvert and I say to them today that that is passed and that you have an opportunity to contribute to the Australian national interest.

I share and support Senator Calvert's comments that we should now look at the big picture. We should look at what all Australian governments of all political persuasions are about, and that is jobs for young Australians, export opportunities for companies and more dollars coming into Australia. As Senator Calvert has outlined, this is a state-of-the-art project that has been held back by politics in the past. We are hoping to say through our joint efforts tonight that politics should no longer hold this project back.

We have some of the biggest corporations in the world interested in helping Australian companies work towards exporting to Japan, as Senator Calvert has indicated. I describe this as a unique opportunity because the flavour created by breeding and slaughtering pigs in Queensland means that they are regarded as premium quality on the Japanese market. There are huge value added dollars and profits to be made, providing we can put together the right sort of package here in Australia and not be held back by the politics.

I do not want to speak for too much longer. I think Senator Calvert has covered all of the relevant aspects, but certainly the message from the coalition and the Labor opposition is that this project deserves to go ahead unencumbered by past debate on the former owners of the piggery. We encourage all concerned to treat this project on its merits. It is deserving of consideration. If people believe the plans that are in place and the project stack up financially, they should not fear that their names will be dragged through the mud. They can have confidence that they will be involved in an excellent project with very positive prospects for Australian jobs and people's futures.

talk.start.para: —In my adjournment speech in the Senate on 5 March 1997, I outlined my concerns over loose taxation exemptions extended to the club sector through the mutuality principle. In a most inadequate assessment on pages 228 and 229, the Ralph report assessed this issue. They missed a chance to address a major tax avoidance matter.

speech.para: The club sector has continued to grow exponentially since I raised my concerns in 1997. Large clubs throughout Australia have diversified into a broad range of commercial activities that are outside their original community based charter. The industry is now involved in operating accommodation properties, ski lodges, cinemas, IMAX theatres, gymnasiums, travel agencies, bus services, hairdressing businesses, bakeries and butcher shops through huge taxpayer subsidies. These enterprises have been enjoying major taxation concessions and exemptions and, in many cases, have resulted in small and local taxpaying businesses being unable to compete with their larger tax-free competitors.

In addition to the multimillion dollar expansion projects undertaken by clubs that I highlighted in 1997, there has been additional building completed and planned for the future. For instance, there is the Twin Towns Services Club in Tweed Heads construction of a $46 million project incorporating a parking station, retail stores, an overhead pedestrian bridge, a hotel and apartments. Additionally, a major buying group, formed in conjunction with Harvey Norman, further emphasises the big business approach of the major clubs. These expansions are undoubtedly commercial enterprises and should be taxed appropriately.

Sporting clubs, where sport is the dominant activity, are presently exempt from paying tax on all their net income, while clubs that partake in more diverse activities are assessed on the Waratah principle, which I believe is now outmoded. The Waratah principle is related to identifying different tax rates for each type of income stream and applies subjective tests under the self-assessment taxation regime. This self-assessment has led to great difficulty in the policing of this tax exemption by the Taxation Commissioner.

The loophole in the mutuality principle must be reformed. The large super clubs continue to dominate, adding to the concerns of not only private business but also smaller clubs that are, in fact, operating within their original charter and are within their right to claim the mutuality principle exemption.

It has become obvious that the smaller clubs are facing the same pressures from super clubs as private enterprise. The larger clubs within Australia not only continue to expand but have begun `McDonaldising' their venues. A number of clubs now operate in excess of five venues under the one banner, with no signs of these clubs slowing their aggressive expansion plans. This form of corporate takeover has resulted from the largest clubs enjoying super profits and being in a cash rich position that has enabled them to continue to capitalise and expand.

The Australian Democrats support the notion of community based organisations and clubs and view smaller, tax exempt club enterprises as legitimate community organisations. The large super clubs, however, are clearly major multimillion dollar commercial enterprises that must be taxed appropriately. Adding further weight to this argument is the relaxed membership process that is employed by the club sector, coupled with marketing initiatives reflecting only nominal regard for the club laws preventing advertising to the public and designed to attract not only local residents but also international tourists. Interestingly, I have been made aware of at least one club now operating marketing offices in overseas locations encouraging overseas tourists to utilise club facilities.

The recently released Productivity Commission Draft report into Australia's gambling industries examined the mutuality principle in detail. Based on Australian clubs' operating profits of $561 million for 1997-98, on page 20.10 of its draft report the Productivity Commission estimated that the government would collect $202 million per annum in taxation revenue if the club sector were taxed at the company tax rate. Other industry sources have suggested that the commission's figures are conservative. The majority of this revenue is generated from the club industry's access to gaming machines and other gambling facilities. In its draft report the commission stated:

There has been a large expansion of part of the club sector in some States and an increased concentration on gambling as their main business. This has skewed the traditional nature of clubs—and has led to the development of super clubs. This then raises the question of whether the club cocktail of mutuality, and a heavily and rapidly growing dependence on gambling revenues by a segment of the club industry, is one which policy makers should accept without restraint.

It is clear that we, the law-makers, should not encourage the continued expansion of this industry through providing taxation exemptions not afforded to other sectors of the community. The mutuality principle is being rorted and is a gross example of an abuse of the taxation system.

The mutuality principle has made it possible for clubs to invest in thousands of gaming machines with no regard to the community's best interests. In New South Wales, for example, the Penrith Panthers Club is currently undergoing major expansion and is on track to be the largest gaming machine provider in New South Wales—larger than Star Casino—and the second largest in Australia, being only slightly smaller than Crown Casino. The Productivity Commission also found that some clubs currently obtain 80 per cent or more of their total revenue from gaming machines—again higher than is found in some casinos. The commission has stated:

In summary, the Commission considers that the exemption of club mutual income from tax, combined with the inability to distribute surpluses to members, has the potential to result in excessive capital allocation in club facilities and other investments.

In my adjournment speech in March 1997, I suggested that there could be merit in ensuring that a figure of, say, four per cent of turnover must be placed back into the community in which these clubs operate. Another alternative is to set a threshold figure at which clubs demutualise and become tax paying entities. I suggest a figure of $1 million turnover as an appropriate amount, a figure used in the Ralph Review of Business Taxation as its basis for the definition of a small business.

Another alternative to this policy approach would be to amend the definition in section 23(g) of the Income Taxation Assessment Act 1936 to require such clubs to satisfy a purpose test each year comparable to the sole purpose test that applies in superannuation legislation. The government faces considerable problems with ensuring that business taxation reform remains revenue neutral. It has consistently stated that all sectors of the community should pay their fair share of taxation. But it has ignored the rich commercial club sector throughout the reform process, despite the major concessions currently extended to the sector. Conservative estimates of $200 million in tax forgone are truly significant.

If the government wishes to ensure revenue neutrality and a fairer and more equitable tax system, it is imperative that this issue be addressed and tightened to reflect a truly progressive, efficient and fair tax system. As I asked in 1997, will the government now review this situation? If it did so and applied appropriate tax rules, it would also assist small business competitors that are being unfairly disadvantaged, would provide revenue to assist in reducing the current revenue shortfall due to the business taxation reform process and would further contribute to the government's budgetary needs. The time has come for the club mutuality principle to be reformed and for $200 million to be raised to fill the black hole which presently exists with the Ralph package.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Appointment of Mr Laurie Foley

talk.start.para: —In the adjournment debate last Thursday, I detailed how a number of candidates were disadvantaged in the selection process for the position of Assistant Director, Aviation Safety Compliance in the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. Tonight I want to talk about the role played by the executive recruitment firm Spencer Stuart in the process that led to the appointment of Mr Laurie Foley to that position. According to Mr Skehill in the report that followed his review of the procedures that led to Mr Foley's appointment, the initial proposal from Mr Wes Willoughby, a special consultant to the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, was:

speech.para: . . . that Spencer Stuart be engaged for that purpose without seeking further expressions of interest from other executive search consultants.

It appears that Mr Willoughby did not follow that course because of the insistence of the Manager, Human Resource Management that there be a proper selection process. I must say that the selection process for the recruitment firm was then carried out in a very efficient manner indeed. CASA contacted six executive recruitment agencies on 15 April 1998. Spencer Stuart provided a detailed proposal just five days later and was given the job on 24 April. A contract was forwarded to Spencer Stuart on 28 April. It contained a clause that stated:
CASA must place a purchase order with the consultant before the consultant begins to carry out the consultant's services.

However, Mr Willoughby ignored that requirement and authorised Mr Wheatley to commence work immediately. Mr Wheatley did not sign the contract until 5 March. This suggests that Mr Willoughby ignored the terms of the contract he was entering into on behalf of CASA or simply ignored those terms.

According to Mr Skehill, some time before 18 May Mr Wheatley prepared a report in relation to Mr Foley based on their meeting on 7 May. Mr Skehill comments that the actual timing of this report is uncertain because it did not bear a clear date. Mr Skehill reported that Mr Wheatley made referee contact with two people not nominated by Mr Foley on 25 May, and it appeared, from Mr Wheatley's notes, that they were both not supportive. On that same day, Mr Wheatley contacted one of the three referees nominated by Mr Foley. That referee was, not surprisingly, supportive. The other two referees nominated by Mr Foley were contacted on 2 June, and again, not surprisingly, they supported his application. So two independent referees did not support Mr Foley and three referees nominated by him were supportive. Mr Wheatley then wrote to Mr Toller on 1 June in the following terms:
Wes and I discussed all the contenders last week and agree on the attached list, which contains full reports on Foley and . . .
And there Mr Skehill's report names a candidate for another position. The quote goes on:
I also append summaries of four new `possibles'.

Note that on that date Mr Wheatley had received reports from three referees, two not supporting Mr Foley and one supporting. I assume that that was reflected in the report to Mr Toller. Mr Skehill discovered, however, that neither Mr Wheatley's file nor the authority's files contained a copy of those lists said to be attached to that letter.

Mr Toller told Mr Skehill that he had no recollection of the letter or the attachments. According to Mr Skehill, Mr Wheatley said he did not have copies because `consistent with his usual practice such would have been maintained on his IT system and then deleted'. This claimed practice is contradicted by other evidence to Mr Skehill's inquiry by Mr Wheatley. Mr Wheatley told Mr Skehill that he had recovered an old file containing information on Mr Foley collected during the recruitment process for the director's position. That process had taken place some considerable time earlier. We can only conclude from this that Mr Wheatley kept some files and not others.

On 3 June Mr Wheatley wrote formal records of the favourable referee reports. These reports were eventually attached to the final report from Spencer Stuart on candidates for Assistant Director, Aviation Safety Compliance provided to the authority on 26 June. Mr Skehill appears to make no reference at all to the fate of the unfavourable referees' reports. I assume, for some reason, they were not included in that report. If those negative assessments were not passed on by Mr Wheatley, that is a serious omission on his part, and that is a matter I will pursue further.

Also, on 26 June, Mr Wheatley interviewed two internal candidates identified in the Skehill report as applicants 12 and 33. According to Mr Skehill, the final Wheatley report `appears to have been prepared prior to that date and did not provide a rating for applicants 12 and 33'. It then says, in brackets: `[although the outcome would not have affected his recommendation on Foley.]'

It is important to note that a board member, Mr Pyne, told Mr Skehill that he insisted that applicants 12 and 33 be interviewed because they rated third and fourth for the position. Despite this view, Mr Wheatley did not even bother to provide the board with a rating for those candidates, based on his interviews with them, in his final report. In fact, it was Mr Willoughby, not Mr Wheatley, who reported to Mr Toller on the outcome of applicant 12 and 33 interviews, and that advice was not provided until some time after 26 June. Then, on 29 June, Mr Wheatley told Mr Toller that, even though he had lodged a formal report some days earlier, the rankings for the safety compliance position were Foley, Mr Y, applicant 12 and applicant 33.

The Skehill report states that the report on Mr Foley contained the fact that Mr Wheatley prepared a final report to the board in late May. As I said earlier, it is not clear whether that report reflected the two negative referee reports.

The report also contained a report on Mr Y. However, that report had been prepared some considerable time earlier as part of an assessment for Mr Y for the position of director. I assume therefore that it did not reflect Mr Y's interview with Mr Willoughby and Mr Wheatley on 11 May 1998. According to Mr Skehill, Mr Y was considered a strong candidate for the Assistant Director, Aviation Safety Compliance position after that May interview. I intend to seek clarification of that point.

The manner in which Spencer Stuart handled the application from Mr X is also of considerable concern. Mr X was advised by Spencer Stuart that he should only lodge an expression of interest and that after an assessment of that application he may be provided with a copy of the selection criteria and invited to lodge a formal application. Mr X then wrote to Spencer Stuart, expressing an interest in the position, on 15 May. That letter was acknowledged by Mr Wheatley four days later. Mr X then discovered that another applicant had been provided with the selection criteria without any sort of application being lodged. He then complained of the manner in which Spencer Stuart was running the selection process and was immediately provided with a copy of the selection criteria.

On 19 May Mr Willoughby told Mr Wheatley that Mr X had not performed well in the position in which he was acting. Mr Wheatley did not check that advice and Mr Skehill concluded that it was in fact wrong. On 29 May Mr Willoughby told Mr Wheatley that Mr X should be dropped off the list because he had another position. Mr Wheatley did not check that claim, and it, too, was wrong. Mr Wheatley then wrote a holding letter to Mr X on 1 June, meaning thereby that, technically at least, he was still a candidate for the job. However, Mr Wheatley failed to include Mr X on the list of candidates he provided to Mr Willoughby, who subsequently submitted them to the board on 19 June. He also failed to make any mention at all of Mr X in the final Spencer Stuart report dated 26 June. According to Mr Skehill, Mr Wheatley could not explain why Mr X had been excluded and `could only attribute this to administrative oversight'.

This omission by Mr Wheatley meant that the board and Mr Toller did not even know Mr X—who was a senior authority employee acting in a position that involved a number of the functions to be undertaken by the Assistant Director, Aviation Safety Compliance—was a candidate for the job. Mr X was also a candidate that, as it transpired, appeared to have a number of supporters on the CASA board. Mr Skehill states in his report, and I quote:
That is perhaps a pity—
that is, that Mr Wheatley did not seek other views on Mr X—

as there had been some differences of view between Mr X and Mr Willoughby about the role, authority and resources of the position in which Mr X was acting, and these may have coloured Mr Willoughby's views of Mr X.
Mr Skehill states further:

Mr Pike says that there were some members of the Board who may have had doubts about Mr X's performance but says that those best qualified to judge would have regarded him as having performed at a high level in difficult circumstances.
Spencer Stuart was paid $200,000 plus 12½ per cent, plus costs, to do the job. It is obvious that our money's worth was not provided in this case.

talk.start.para: —This evening I would like to present the Senate with a description and a report of my recent trip to the Bailiwick of Guernsey, which is something that I know you, Madam President, would also be interested in. It occurred on my way to the 45th Commonwealth Parliamentary Association General Meeting in Trinidad, on which I do not intend to provide a report tonight. That will occur when those who went on that delegation present their report to the Senate. It arose out of my membership of the Joint Standing Committee on National Capital and External Territories. So why, you may ask, would I have taken the opportunity to go to Guernsey? Currently before this parliament there is legislation in respect of Norfolk Island, which I do not intend to go into tonight. That committee was led to discussions about comparing arrangements on islands such as Guernsey—or another island in the Channel Islands, Jersey—with the arrangements that Norfolk Island has with Australia. While I was on the other side of the world I took the opportunity to fly from London to Guernsey to have a look at that Bailiwick and to meet the people involved in running the island.

speech.para: The Channel Islands are regarded, geographically, as part of the British Isles. The two Bailiwicks of Guernsey and Jersey are independent jurisdictions separate from the United Kingdom and in that respect are quite different from Wales or Scotland and Northern Ireland. Guernsey has a population of around 59,000, of whom 38,000 were born locally. It would be true to say that the scenes from the top of the cliffs and the views of the beaches are picture postcard perfect, although probably not as good as what you might see around some of the coastline of Australia. I am sure that people in Guernsey who receive a copy of this speech will forgive me for being a little biased about that. Guernsey is certainly a very beautiful and historic place and, as you move around the small island, you can almost sense the history of the place and the way in which the people are ever so proud of that history. For Australians trying to picture what it would be like, they may well remember the television show Bergerac, which was filmed either on that island or on an island similar to it. It is where Victor Hugo lived between 1855 and 1870 while he finished his work Les Miserables. We in Australia would all be familiar with that, being a very famous stage production.

The Guernsey Tourist Board has produced a terrific booklet that outlines life on the Bailiwick of Guernsey. I am not an expert on Guernsey history, so I would need to refer to this booklet in outlining some of the historical nature of that place. You need to look at where Guernsey has come from in order to appreciate some of the aspects under which they live today. Geographically, Guernsey is much closer to France than to England. It lies only 30 miles from the Normandy Coast, as against 80 miles from Weymouth, which is the closest point on the United Kingdom coast. When islanders talk about the mainland they actually mean the United Kingdom, to which they are bound by centuries of sentiment, economies and politics. Back in 933 AD the Channel Islands became part of the Norman realms. This followed the treaty of St Clair-sur-Epte. Later in 1066, William, the Duke of Normandy, landed his conquering army in Sussex and became William I of England. His Duchy of Normandy included the Channel Islands and these became part of the combined realm of England and Normandy. Some 138 years later, King John lost most of the Duchy of Normandy, but Guernsey and the other Channel Islands remained loyal to the British Crown.

One of the things that struck me when talking to the people on Guernsey about their relationship with the United Kingdom was that they were very strong in the resolve that their allegiance is to the Crown of the United Kingdom as opposed to the parliament of the United Kingdom. Of course, the Germans invaded the Channel Islands in July 1940 and the islands were occupied for nearly five years by Hitler's forces. Thousands of local people were evacuated to the United Kingdom, but a generation of children have since grown up in the towns and villages. The Guernsey people are proud of the fact that their fealty to the English Crown has been by choice and not by conquest. Indeed, as islanders sometimes pointed out to me with tongue in cheek, it was their duke that conquered England in 1066, because he arrived first on the island of Guernsey.

Citizens from the United Kingdom can go to Guernsey without a passport in a similar way to the majority of the Australian population who visit Norfolk Island. They find that the United Kingdom provides them with perhaps a sense of being home but also of being abroad. The Channel Islands, of which the Bailiwick of Guernsey forms part, occupy an unusual position in Her Majesty's possessions for they are not part of the United Kingdom, nor are they sovereign states or colonies. Guernsey has its own government. It makes its own laws and fixes its own taxes. It has no representatives in the British parliament, nor do the citizens of Guernsey vote in British parliamentary elections. The basis of the island's constitution is an ancient loyalty to the British Crown, as I have said, as opposed to the British parliament. It has been allowed for centuries to run its own affairs while being able to export its products duty free to the British mainland.

The British government could legislate for the island but it has never done so, I am told, in the interests of good government. The government of the United Kingdom is responsible only for defence and international relations in respect of Guernsey, but they tell me that the Guernsey government is first consulted about these matters. The administration is responsible through the Queen and the Privy Council, the ultimate court of appeal being the judicial court of the Privy Council.

Under protocol 3 of the United Kingdom's Treaty of Accession to the European Union, Guernsey is within the European Union for the purposes of trade but out of it for almost everything else. On the other hand, the island does not qualify for EU financial aid.

The island parliament is called the States of Deliberation, which is usually referred to simply as the `States'. It has 57 members, 45 elected by popular vote, 10 elected by parish councils and two representatives from the nearby island of Alderney. Alderney has a population in similar numbers to Norfolk Island. Tax is paid to Guernsey for essential services and a levy is paid through property tax. However, Guernsey makes up the shortfall in funding and development of infrastructure.

It is interesting to note that Guernsey has only recently changed its eligibility laws for those wanting to be registered on the electoral roll. Until recently, you had to be either a British subject or from a country of the Commonwealth or the Republic of Ireland and have lived on the island for two years. With the recent change, in order to register, you only have to have been a resident on the island between 1 September and 31 October of that year in which you seek registration. You must have been resident for a period of two years immediately preceding that date or at any time before that date for a period or a period of at least five years in total. They have actually expanded their representation but are still trying to maintain the uniqueness of having lived on the island for a number of years before you get an opportunity to vote for their parliament. Guernsey receives no grant of any kind from the British government. The island has a self-supporting economy. This is mainly in financial services and tourism.

Before finishing tonight, I particularly want to pay tribute to the people I met on the island. They include Mr Talmai Morgan, the Director of Fiduciary Services and Enforcement; and Mr Philip Marr, the Director of Banking, who spent time explaining to me at length the economic infrastructure of the island. I also met with Mr David Robilliard, the Head of External and Constitutional Affairs. Finally, I met Mr Mike Torode, who is a senior member of the States of Guernsey. I spent quite an interesting time chatting to him over lunch and having a personal tour of the island. I want to place on record my thanks to Anne Robilliard, the Deputy of the States of Guernsey, who had an opportunity to further discuss and clarify the issues of Guernsey at the CPA conference.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Department of Industry, Science and Resources Preparation
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1414)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 2 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to the effect of the goods and services tax (GST) on the internal operations of the Minister's portfolio (that is, not relating to the services provided to the public), and in relation to each of the
agencies within the portfolio:
(1) What preparations have been undertaken to date in regard to the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000.

(2) (a) What has been the total cost of those actions already undertaken; and (b) how much of these costs relate to: (i) consultancies, (ii) staff training, (iii) computer software, (iv) extra staff, (v) stationery, and (vi) other (please specify).
(3) Was the cost of undertaking this work included in the
portfolio's 1999-2000 budget appropriation; if so, how was this funding identified; if not, what other area of funding has been used for this purpose.
(4) What future preparations are planned or expected to be required in regard to the introduction of the GST on 1 July 2000.

(5) (a) What is the total cost of the actions planned, or the estimated cost of expected actions; and (b) how much of these costs relate to: (i) consultancies, (ii) staff training, (iii) computer software, (iv) extra staff, (v) stationery, and (vi) other (please specify).

(6) Was the estimated cost of undertaking this future work included in the portfolio's 1999-2000 budget appropriation; if so, how was this funding identified; if not, what other area of funding has been used
for this purpose.
(7) Is there expected to be any change in the ongoing running costs of the department/agency after the commencement of the GST; if so, what is the extent of the difference in costs.
(8) Are there any other GST-associated costs which the portfolio agencies will incur prior to the commencement of the GST; if so, what are those costs.

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator Minchin
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Preparations undertaken to date within the Industry, Science and Resources portfolio for the introduction of the GST include:
* establishment of GST working groups;
* examination of the impact of the GST and development of
implementation strategies;
* engagement of consultants to help identify compliance effects of GST
legislation and oversee implementation of these;
* examination of GST requirements for financial management information systems;
* attendance at seminars and liaison with other government agencies; and
* commencement of staff training.
(2) Expenditure incurred to date includes expenditure relating to the provision of services to
the public. The portion of cost relating to the internal operations of the portfolio is not separable.
(3) No additional funds were allocated in the 1999-2000 budget appropriation for GST implementation. These costs have been met from existing funds.
(4) Future preparations within the Industry, Science and Resources portfolio for the introduction of the GST are expected to include:
* refine and finalise GST implementation strategies;
* modify accounting systems and procedures to comply with the GST legislation;
* ensure that financial management information systems (FMIS) are GST capable, upgrade systems as required, provide relevant training;
* implement systems, policy and procedural changes to ensure GST obligations are met;
* ensure that computer systems are GST compliant;
* test internal procedures, undertake internal audits to ensure readiness for implementation of GST;
* review existing contracts (as appropriate), obtain legal advice on contract clauses relating to the GST; and
* focus on internal awareness, conduct further staff training.
(5) The overall cost of actions planned within the portfolio has not been determined, but is expected to be small in relation to overall budget running costs.
(6) No additional funds were allocated in the 1999-2000 budget appropriation for GST implementation. These costs will be met from existing funds.

(7) It is not expected that the introduction of the GST will result in major changes to the ongoing running costs of the department and portfolio agencies. The extent of any difference in costs has not been identified at this time.
(8) At this stage, no other GST-associated costs (relating to the internal operations of the department and portfolio agencies) have been identified.

subdebateinfo.title: Royal Australian Navy Ammunition Facility, Twofold Bay, New South Wales
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1428)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 15 September 1999:

question.para: With reference to the proposal to locate the East Coast Armaments Complex at Twofold Bay in New South Wales:

(1) Have the feasibility studies and environmental assessment referred to in the answer to question on notice no. 607 (Senate Hansard, 11 May 1999, p.4796) been completed; if so, can copies be provided; if not, when will they be completed and released.
(2) (a) What is the process and timetable for the Twofold Bay proposal; and (b) have there been any changes or other developments relating to the proposal since March 1999.
(3) Are any other locations under consideration for all or part of the original East Coast Armaments Complex concept.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Detailed technical and environmental investigations are nearing completion. The findings of these investigations are being incorporated into the proposal that will be referred to Parliament for consideration by the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works (PWC) and the Draft Environmental Impact Statement that is proposed for public exhibition commencing 8 November 1999. The statement of evidence to the PWC will be available through the PWC Secretariat following referral of the proposal in Parliament, which is expected in October 1999. The Draft Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) will be available after publication, scheduled for early November 1999.
(2) (a) The process is as outlined in the answer part (1) above. The proposed timetable is:
. Referral to Parliament October 1999
. Public exhibition of draft EIS 8 November—17 December 1999
. Parliamentary and environmental approval February/March 2000
. Contract let mid 2000
. Construction complete end 2001
(b) No.

(3) Yes. The original East Coast Armament Complex concept for Point Wilson had two components: ammunitioning of Navy ships and bulk importation of Defence explosive ordnance. The proposal for Twofold Bay will cater for the Navy ammunitioning requirement currently conducted in Sydney Harbour. The importation of explosive ordnance is being addressed separately in the current market testing of Defence explosive ordnance storage, maintenance and distribution. The location for import of Defence explosive ordnance will be decided by the successful commercial operator.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service: Live Animal Export Program
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1431)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 17 September 1999:

question.para: What proportion of the funding for the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service Live Animal Export Program is:
(a) paid for by industry through export licences, auditing costs and other fees collected from the export industry; and
(b) directed towards fulfilling its responsibilities to protect the welfare of live animals for export, as distinct from its veterinary health responsibilities.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (a) Government policy requires the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service's (AQIS) Live Animal Export Program and all other operational programs to operate on a fully cost recovered basis. All program expenditure is therefore recovered from the live animal export industry in the form of fees for services provided.

(b) The Live Animal Export Program is responsible for the provision of export documentation to accompany live animal export consignments. Export documentation is only issued when AQIS is satisfied that all importing country animal health requirements have been met and appropriate animal welfare practices have been followed in the preparation of the consignment for export. As the animal welfare practices are part of the overall industry and AQIS inspection, auditing and certification processes, it is not possible to separate the resources allocated to veterinary health responsibilities and animal welfare responsibilities.

subdebateinfo.title: Department of Defence: Freedom of Information Requests
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1481)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 20 September 1999:

question.para: (1) What are the: (a) formal qualifications; (b) relevant experience; and (c) employment classification/grade, of each departmental officer who has made initial stage decisions regarding requests under the Freedom of Information Act since 3 March 1996.

(2) What are the: (a) formal qualifications; (b) relevant experience; and (c) employment classification/grade, of each departmental officer who has made internal review decisions regarding requests under the Freedom of Information Act since 3 March 1996.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator Newman
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) and (2) The Minister is not prepared to authorise the diversion of resources from other work, including the processing of requests made under the Freedom of Information Act, that would be required to provide the level of detail sought by the honourable senator. However, the following information describes, in broad terms, the arrangements for FOI decision-making in the Department of Defence and the Defence Force.

By authority of section 23 of the Freedom of Information Act 1982 (FOI Act), the Secretary to the Department of Defence has granted decision-making authority for FOI to various offices and ranks throughout the Department and the Defence Force. The Secretary has devolved authority so that decisions on requests are made in offices with jurisdiction over the documents or information involved and by persons who have competence to judge the status of the documents or information under the FOI Act. Otherwise the formal qualifications and relevant experience of the individual decision-makers are not recorded.

Officers holding the rank of Colonel (equivalent) and Australian Public Service Executive Level 2 officers, or higher, may authorise the disclosure of documents. A commanding officer of a Defence Force unit may authorise the disclosure of documents provided that the officer occupies the rank of Lieutenant Colonel (equivalent). Brigadier (equivalent) officers and Australian Public Service officers in the Senior Executive Service may refuse access to documents. Authority to make decisions about FOI application fees and charges is exercised by an officer other than the one who decides whether or not to grant access to the document/s requested.

Authority to make decisions about requests for amendment or annotation of records of personal information is held by senior managers in the Defence Personnel Executive and by Managers of Defence Corporate Support Centres.

Authority to undertake internal review of decisions made on requests under the FOI Act has been devolved to the Chief of the Defence Force, the Deputy Secretaries, the Service Chiefs and Deputy Chiefs, Group managers, some deputy Group managers, the Director General Defence Corporate Support—Bases, the Director General Defence Legal Office and General Counsel.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 28 September 1999:

question.para: (1) Is it a fact that Telstra now wants to cut $2 billion in costs and 9000 jobs; if so, does this measure have the Government's and the Minister's support.

(2) Is a $2 billion cut in the public interest; if so, why; if not, will section 9 of the Telstra Corporation Limited Act 1991 be used by the Minister to provide directions to the Telstra Board in the public interest.
(3) What discussions have taken place between the Minister and Telstra regarding this issue.
(4) As a result of these cuts: (a) how many jobs will be lost in regional and rural areas; and (b) what will be the breakdown, by state.
(5) What are the implications of these cuts for services in rural Australia.
(6) Has the advice of the Australian Communications Authority been sought in respect of these cuts; if so, what was that advice.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Telstra's announcement of a cost reduction initiative is part of its continuing search for improvement. Telstra has indicated that the objective is not staff reductions, but improved ways of working. Telstra has not identified a particular figure on cost reductions and while job reductions in the long run have not been ruled out, any numbers are just speculation. As the Government has noted on many previous occasions the day-to-day operation of Telstra is a matter entirely for its Board and management, it is not for the Government to intervene.

(2) As noted in the response to Question (1), no specific figure for cost reductions has been identified. The Government does not intend to intervene in the operations of a partly owned Commonwealth Government Business Enterprise to instruct it as to what expenses it should and should not review. Telstra is well aware of the legislated requirements in respect of customer service standards and service obligations.
(3) No discussion has taken place on this issue between the Minister and Telstra.
(4) See answer to Question (1)
(5) Telstra has indicated it remains committed to service improvement in rural Australia.
(6) No advice has been sought from the ACA in respect of this issue.
